note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Bonduca, Daughters, Hengo, Nennius, Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: _THe hardy Romanes? O ye gods of Britain,
the ruſt of Arms, the bluſhing ſhame of ſouldiers;
are theſe the men that conquer by inheritance?
the Fortune-makers? theſe the Julians,
that with the Sun meaſure the end of Nature,
making the world but one Rome and one Caeſar?
Shame, how they flee! Caeſars ſoft ſoul dwells in 'em;
their mothers got 'em ſleeping, pleaſure nurſt 'em,
their bodies ſweat with ſweet oils, loves allurements,
not luſtie Arms. Dare they ſend theſe to ſeek us,
theſe Romane Girls? Is Britain grown ſo wanton?
Twice we have beat 'em, Nennius, ſcatter'd 'em,
and through their big-bon'd Germans, on whoſe Pikes
the honour of their actions ſit in triumph,
made Themes for ſongs to ſhame 'em, and a woman,
a woman beat'em, Nennius; a weak woman,
a woman beat theſe Romanes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: So it ſeems.
A man would ſhame to talk ſo.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Couſin, do you grieve my fortunes?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No, Bonduca,
if I grieve, 't is the bearing of your fortunes;
you put too much winde to your ſail: Diſcretion
and hardie Valour are the twins of Honour,
and nurs'd together, make a Conquerour:
divided, but a talker. 'T is a truth,
that Rome has fled before us twice, and routed;
a truth we ought to crown the gods for, Lady,
and not our tongues. A truth is none of ours,
nor in our ends, more then the noble bearing:
for then it leaves to be a vertue, Lady;
and we that have been Victors, beat our ſelves,
when we inſult upon our honours ſubject.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: My valiant Couſin, is it foul to ſay
what liberty and honour bid us do,
and what the gods allow us?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No, Bonduca,
ſo what we ſay, exceed not what we do.
Ye call the Romanes fearful, fleeing Romanes,
and Romane Girls, the lees of tainted pleaſures:
does this become a doer? are they ſuch?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: They are no more.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Where is your Conqueſt then?
why are your Altars crown'd with wreathes of flowers,
the beaſts with gilt horns waiting for the fire?
the holy Druides compoſing ſongs
of everlaſting life to Victory?
Why are theſe triumphs, Lady? for a May-game?
for hunting a poor herd of wretched Romanes?
is it no more? ſhut up your Temples, Britains,
and let the Husband-man redeem his heifers;
put out our holy fires; no Timbrel ring;
let's home, and ſleep; for ſuch great overthrows,
a Candle burns too bright a ſacrifice,
a Glow-worms tail too full a flame. O Nennius,
thou hadſt a noble Uncle knew a Romane,
and how to ſpeak him, how to give him weight
in both his fortunes.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: By—I think
ye doat upon theſe Romanes, Caratach.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Witneſſe theſe wounds, I do; they were fairly given.
I love an enemy: I was born a ſouldier;
and he that in the head on 's Troop defies me,
bending my manly body with his ſword,
I make a Miſtris. Yellow-treſſed Hymen
ne'er ty'd a longing Virgin with more ioy,
then I am married to that man that wounds me:
and are not all theſe Romane? Ten ſtruck Battels
I ſuckt theſe honour'd ſcars from, and all Romane:
ten yeers of bitter nights and heavie marches,
when many a frozen ſtorm ſung thorow my Curaſſe,
and made it doubtful whether that or I
were the more ſtubborn metal, have I wrought thorow,
and all to try theſe Romanes. Ten times a night
I have ſwom the Rivers, when the ſtars of Rome
ſhot at me as I ſloated, and the billows
tumbled their watry ruines on my ſhoulders,
charging my batter'd ſides with troops of Agues;
and ſtill to try theſe Romanes, whom I found
(and if I lye, my wounds be henceforth backward,
and be you witneſſe, gods, and all my dangers)
as ready, and as full of that I brought
(which was not fear nor flight) as valiant,
as vigilant, as wiſe, to do and ſuffer,
ever advanced as forward as the Britains,
their ſleeps as ſhort, their hopes as high as ours,
I, and as ſubtil, Lady. 'T is diſhonour,
and, follow'd, will be impudence, Bonduca,
and grow to no belief, to taint theſe Romance.
Have not I ſeen the Britains—

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Diſhearted,
run, run, Bonduca, not the quick rack ſwifter;
the virgin from the hated raviſher
not half ſo fearful? not a flight drawn home,
a round ſtone from a Sling, a lovers wiſh
ere made that haſte that they have. By—
I have ſeen theſe Britains, that you magnifie,
run ●s they would have out-run time, and roaring
baſely for mercy, roaring: the light ſhadows
that in a thought ſcur ore the fields of Corn,
halted on crutches to 'em.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: O ye Powers,
what ſcandals do I ſuffer?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Yes, Bonduca,
I have ſeen thee run too, and thee, Nennius;
yea, run apace, both; then when Penyus
the Romane Girl cut thorow your armed Carts,
and drive 'em headlong on ye down the hill;
then when he hunted ye, like Britain-Foxes,
more by the ſent then ſight: then did I ſee
theſe valiant and approved men of Britain,
like boading Owls, creep into tods of Ivie,
and hoot their fears to one another nightly.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: And what did you then, Caratach?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I fled too,
but not ſo faſt; your Jewel had been loſt then,
young Hengo there; he traſht me, Nennius:
for when your fears out-run him, then ſtept I,
and in the head of all the Romane fury
took him, and with my tough Belt to my back
I buckled him; behinde him, my ſure Shield;
and then I follow'd. If I ſay I fought
five times in bringing off this bud of Britain,
I lye not, Nennius. Neither had ye heard
me ſpeak this, or ever ſeen the childe more,
but that the ſon of vertue, Penyus,
ſeeing me ſteer thorow all theſe ſtorms of danger,
my helm ſtill in my hand, my ſword my prow,
turn'd to my ſo my face, he cri'd out nobly,
Go, Britain, bear thy Lions whelp off ſafely;
thy manly ſword has ranſom'd thee: grow ſtrong,
and let me meet thee once again in arms;
then if thou ſtand'ſt, thou art mine. I took his offer,
and here I am to honour him.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: O Couſin,
from what a flight of honour haſt thou checkt me?
what wouldſt thou make me, Caratach?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: See, Lady,
the noble uſe of others in our loſſes;
does this afflict ye? Had the Romanes cri'd this,
and as we have done theirs, ſung out theſe fortunes,
rail'd on our baſe condition, hooted at us,
made marks as far as the earth was ours, to ſhew us
nothing but ſea could ſtop our flights; deſpis'd us,
and held it equal whether banquetting
or beating of the Britains were more buſineſſe,
it would have gall'd ye.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Let me think we conquer'd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Do; but ſo think, as we may be conquer'd:
and where we have found vertue, though in thoſe
that came to make us ſlaves, let's cheriſh it.
There's not a blowe we gave ſince Julius landed,
that was of ſtrength and worth, but like Records
they file to after-ages. Our Regiſters,
the Romanes, are for noble deeds of honour;
and ſhall we burn their mentions with upbraidings?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: No more, I ſee my ſelf: thou haſt made me, Couſin,
more then my fortunes durſt; for they abus'd me,
and wound me up ſo high, I ſwell'd with glory:
thy temperance has cur'd that Tympany,
and given me health again, nay, more diſcretion.
Shall we have peace? for now I love theſe Romanes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thy love and hate are both unwiſe ones, Lady.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Your reaſon?

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Is not Peace the end of Arms?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Not where the cauſe implies a general Conqueſt:
had we a difference with ſome pettie Iſle,
or with our neighbours (Lady) for our Land-marks,
the taking in of ſome rebellious Lord,
or making a head againſt Commotions,
after a day of Blood, Peace might be argued:
But where we grapple for the ground we live on,
the Libertie we hold as dear as life,
the gods we worſhip, and next thoſe, our Honours,
and with thoſe ſwords that know no end of Battel:
thoſe men beſide themſelves allow no neighbour;
thoſe mindes that where the day is claim inheritance,
and where the ſun makes ripe the fruits, their harveſt,
and where they march, but meaſure out more ground
to adde to Rome, and here i'th' bowels on us;
it muſt not be; no, as they are our foes,
and thoſe that muſt be ſo until we tire 'em,
let 's uſe the peace of Honour, that 's fair dealing,
but in our ends, our ſwords. That hardy Romane
that hopes to graft himſelf into my ſtock,
muſt firſt begin his kinred under ground,
and be alli'd in aſhes.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: as thou haſt nobly ſpoken, ſhall be done;
and Hengo to thy charge I here deliver:
the Romanes ſhall have worthy Wars.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: They ſhall.
And, little Sir, when your young bones grow ſtiffer,
and when I ſee ye able in a morning
to beat a dozen boys, and then to breakfaſt,
I'll tye ye to a ſword.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: And what then, Uncle?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Then ye muſt kill, Sir, the next valiant Romane
that calls ye knave.

sp.speaker: Hengo.
sp.l: And muſt I kill but one?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: An hundred, boy, I hope.

sp.speaker: Hengo.
sp.l: I hope five hundred.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That 's a noble boy. Come, worthy Lady,
let's to our ſeveral charges, and henceforth
allow an enemy both weight and worth. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Junius and Petillius, two Romane Captains.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: What ailſt thou, man? doſt thou want meat?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Clothes?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Neither. For heavens love, leave me.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Drink?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Ye tire me.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Come, 't is drink; I know 't is drink.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: 'T is no drink.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I ſay 't is drink: for what affliction
can light ſo heavie on a Souldier,
to dry him up as thou art, but no drink?
Thou ſhalt have drink.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Prethee, Petillius—

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And by mine honour, much drink, valiant drink:
never tell me, thou ſhalt have drink. I ſee,
like a true friend, into thy wants: 'tis drink;
and when I leave thee to a deſolation,
eſpecially of that dry nature, hang me.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Why do you do this to me?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: For I ſee▪
although your modeſtie would fain conceal it,
which ſits as ſweetly on a Souldier,
as an old ſide-ſaddle.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: What do you ſee?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I ſee as far as day, that thou want'ſt drink.
Did I not finde thee gaping like an Oyſter
for a new tide? thy very thoughts lie bare
like a lowe ebbe? thy ſoul that rid in Sack,
lies moor'd for want of liquor? Do but ſee
into thy ſelf; for by—I do:
for all thy body 's chapt, and crackt like timber
for want of moiſture: what thou wantſt there, Junius,
and if it be not drink.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: You have too much on 't.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: It may be a whore too; ſay it be: come, meecher,
thou ſhalt have both: a pretty valiant fellow,
die for a little lap and lechery?
no, it ſhall ne'er be ſaid in our Countrey,
thou dy'dſt o'th' Chin-cough. Heare, thou noble Romane,
the ſon of her that loves a Souldier,
hear what I promiſed for thee; thus I ſaid,
Lady, I take thy ſon to my companion,
Lady, I love thy ſon, thy ſon loves war,
the war loves danger, danger drink, drink diſcipline,
which is ſociety and lechery;
theſe two beget Commanders: fear not, Lady,
thy ſon ſhall lead.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: 'T is a ſtrange thing, Petillius,
that ſo ridiculous and looſe a mirth
can maſter your affections.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Any mirth,
and any way, of any ſubject, Junius,
is better then unmanly muſtineſſe:
what harm's in drink, in a good wholeſom wench?
I do beſeech ye, Sir, what errour? yet
it cannot out of my head handſomly,
but thou wouldſt fain be drunk: come, no more fooling,
the General has new wine, new come over.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: He muſt have new acquaintance for it too,
for I will none, I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: None, I thank ye?
a ſhort and touchie anſwer. None I thank ye:
ye do not ſcorn it, do ye?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Gods defend Sir;
I owe him ſtill more honour.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: None, I thank ye:
no company, no drink, no wench, I thank ye.
Ye ſhall be worſe intreated, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: as thou art honeſt, leave me.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: None, I thank ye;
a modeſt and a decent reſolution,
and well put on. Yes, I will leave ye, Junius,
and leave ye to the boys, that very ſhortly
ſhall all ſalute ye, by your new ſirname
of Junius none I thank ye. I would ſtarve now,
hang, drown, deſpair, deſerve the forks, lie open
to all the dangerous paſſes of a wench,
bound to believe her tears, and wed her aches,
ere I would own thy follies. I have found ye,
your lays, and out-leaps Junius, haunts, and lodges:
I have view'd ye, and I have found ye by my skill
to be a fool o'th' firſt head, Junius,
and I will hunt ye: ye are in love, I know it:
ye are an aſle, and all the Camp ſhall know
a peeviſh idle boy; your dame ſhall know it;
a wronger of my care; your ſelf ſhall know it.

div.stage: Enter Corporal Judas, and four ſouldiers.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: A Bean? a princely diet, a full banquet,
to what we compaſſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.l: Fight like hogs for Acorns?

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.l: Venture our lives for pig-nuts?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: What ail theſe Raſcals?

sp.speaker: 3 Sould.
sp.l: If this hold, we are ſtarv'd.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: For my part, friends,
which is but twenty Beans a day, a hard world
for Officers, and men of action;
and thoſe ſo clipt by maſter mouſe, and rotten:
for underſtand 'em French Beans, where the fruits
are ripen'd like the people, in old tubs.
For mine own part, I ſay, I am ſtarv'd already,
not worth another Bean, conſum'd to nothing,
nothing but fleſh and bones left, miſerable:
now if this muſtie provender can prick me
to honourable matters of atchievement, Gentlemen,
why there's the point.

sp.speaker: 4 Sould.
sp.l: I'll fight no more.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: You'll hang then,
a ſoveraign help for hunger. Ye eating Raſcals,
whoſe gods are Beef and Brewis, whoſe brave angers
do execution upon theſe, and Chibbals:
ye dogs heads i' th' porridge pot; you fight no more?
does Rome depend upon your reſolution
for eating mouldy pie-cruſt?

sp.speaker: 3 Sould.
sp.l: Would we had it.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: I may do ſervice, Captain.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: In a Fiſh-market.
You, Corporal Curry-comb, what will your fighting
profit the Common-wealth? do you hope to triumph,
or dare your vamping valour, good man Cobler,
clap a new ſoal to th' Kingdom? s' death, ye dog-whelps
you, fight, or not fight.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Out, ye fleſh-flyes,
nothing but noyce and naſtineſſe.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Give us meat,
whereby we may do.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Whereby hangs your valor?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Good bits afford good blows.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: A good poſition:
how long is 't ſince thou eat'ſt laſt? wipe thy mouth,
and then tell truth.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: I have not eat to th' purpoſe—

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: To th' purpoſe? what's that? half a Cow, and Garlick?
ye Rogues, my Company eat Turf, and talk not;
timber they can digeſt, and fight upon 't;
old matts, and mud with ſpoons, rare meats. Your ſhoes, ſlaves,
dare ye cry out of hunger, and thoſe extant?
ſuck your Sword-hilts, ye ſlaves, if ye be valiant;
honour will make 'em march-pain: to the purpoſe?
a grievous penance. Doſt thou ſee that Gentleman,
that melancholy Monſieur?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Pray ye, Petillius.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: He has not eat theſe three weeks.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.l: 'has drunk the more then.

sp.speaker: 3 Sould.
sp.l: And that 's all one.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Nor drunk nor ſlept theſe two months.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.p: Captain, We do beſeech you as poor Souldiers, men that have ſeen good days, whoſe mortal ſtomacks may ſomtime feel afflictions.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: This, Petillius,
is not ſo nobly done.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: 'T is common profit;
urge him to th' point, he 'll finde you out a food
that needs no teeth nor ſtomack; a ſtrange formity
will feed ye up as fat as hens i' th' foreheads,
and make ye fight like Fichocks, to him.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Cap●ain.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Do you long to have your throats cut?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: See what metal
it makes in him: two meals more of this melancholy,
and there lies Caratach.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: We do beſeech ye.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.l: Humbly beſeech your valour.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Am I onely
become your ſport, Petillius?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: But to render
in way of general good, in preſervation.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Out of my thoughts, ye ſlaves.

sp.speaker: 4 Sould.
sp.l: Or rather pitie.

sp.speaker: 3 Sould
sp.l: Your warlike remedy againſt the maw-worms.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Or notable receipt to live by nothing.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Out with your Table-books.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Is this true friendſhip?
and muſt my killing griefs make others May-games?
Stand from my ſwords point, ſlaves; your poor ſtarv'd ſpirits
can make me no oblations; elſe, O love,
thou proudly blind deſtruction, I would ſend thee
whole Hecatombs of hearts, to bleed my ſorrows.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Alas, he lives by love, Sir, Exit Junius.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: So he does, Sir,
and cannot you do ſo too? All my Company
are now in love, ne'er think of meat, nor talk
of what Provant is: aymees, and hearty hey-hoes,
are Sallets fit for Souldiers. Live by meat,
by larding up your bodies? 't is lewd, and lazie,
and ſhews ye meerly mortal, dull, and drives ye
to fight like Camels, with baskets at your noſes.
Get ye in love; ye can whore well enough,
that all the world knows: faſt ye into Famine,
yet ye can crawl like Crabs to wenches, handſomly.
Fall but in love now, as ye ſee example,
and follow it but with all your thoughts, probatum,
there's ſo much charge ſav'd, and your hungers ended.
Away, I hear the General: get ye in love all, Drum afar off.
up to the ears in love, that I may hear
no more of theſe rude murmurings; and diſcreetly
carry your ſtomacks, or I propheſie
a pickel'd rope will choke ye. Jog, and talk not. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Swetonius, Demetrius, Decius, Drum, Colours.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Demetrius, is the meſſenger diſpatch'd
to Penyus, to command him to bring up
the Volans Regiment?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: He 's there by this time.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: And are the horſe well view'd we brought from Mona?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: The Troops are full, and luſty.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Good Petillius,
look to thoſe eating Rogues, that bawl for victuals,
and ſtop their throats a day or two: proviſion
waits but the winde to reach us.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Sir, already
I have been tampring with their ſtomacks, which I finde
as deaf as Adders to delays: your clemency
hath made their murmurs, mutinies, nay, rebellions:
now, and they want but Muſtard, they 're in uproars:
no oil but Candy, Lucitanian figs,
and wine from Leſtos, now can ſatisfie 'em:
the Britiſh waters are grown dull and muddy,
the fruit diſguſtful: Orontes muſt be ſought for,
and Apples from the happie Iſles: the truth is,
they are more curious now in having nothing,
then if the ſea and land turn'd up their treaſures:
this loſt the Colonies, and gave Bonduca
(with ſhame we muſt reco●d it) time and ſtrength
to look into our Fortunes; great diſcretion
to follow offered Victory; and laſt, full pride
to brave us to our teeth, and ſcorn our ruines.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Nay, chide not, good Petillius, I confeſſe
my will to conquer Mona, and long ſtay
to execute that will, let in theſe loſſes:
all ſhall be right again, and as a pine
rent from Oeta by a ſweeping tempeſt,
joynted again, and made a Maſt, defies
thoſe angry windes that ſplit him: ſo will I,
piec'd to my never-failing ſtrength and fortune,
ſteer thorow theſe ſwelling dangers, plow their prides up,
and bear like thunder through their loudeſt tempeſts:
they keep the field ſtill.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Confident and full.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: In ſuch a number, one would ſwear they grew,
the hills are wooded with their partizans,
and all the valleys over-grown with darts,
as moors are with rank ruſhes: no ground left us
to charge upon, no room to ſtrike: ſay fortune
and our endeavours bring us in to 'em,
they are ſo infinite, ſo ever ſpringing,
we ſhall be kill'd with killing; of deſperate women,
that neither fear, or ſhame ere found, the devill
has rankt amongſt 'em multitudes: ſay the men fail,
they 'll poiſon us with their petticoats: ſay they fail,
they have prieſts enough to pray us into nothing.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Theſe are imaginations, dreams of nothings,
the man that doubts or fears.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: I am free of both.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: The ſelf-ſame I.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And I as free as any;
as careleſſe of my fleſh, of that we call life,
ſo I may loſe it nobly; as indifferent
as if it were my diet. Yet, noble General,
it was a wiſedom learn'd from you; I learn'd it,
and worthy of a Souldiers care, moſt worthy,
to weigh with moſt deliberate circumſtance
the ends of accidents, above their offers;
how to go on and get, to ſave a Romane,
whoſe on● life is more worth in way of doing,
then millions of theſe painted waſps; how viewing
to finde advantage out; how, found, to follow it
with counſel and diſcretion, leſt meer fortune
ſhould claim the victory.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: 'Tis true, Petillius,
and worthily remembred: the rule's certain,
their uſes no leſſe excellent: but where time
cuts off occaſions, danger, time and all
tend to a preſent peril, 't is required
our Swords and Manhoods be beſt counſellors,
our expeditions, preſidents. To win, is nothing,
where reaſon, time and counſel are our Camp-maſters:
but there to bear the field, then to be conquerours,
where pale deſtruction takes us, takes us beaten,
in wants, and mutinies, our ſelves but handfuls,
and to our ſelves our own fears, needs a new way,
a ſudden and a deſperate execution:
here, how to ſave, is loſſe; to be wiſe, dangerous;
onely a preſent well-united ſtrength,
and mindes made up for all attempts, diſpatch it:
diſputing and delay here, cools the courage;
neceſſity gives time for doubts; things infinite,
according to the ſpirit they are preach'd to,
rewards like them; and names for after-ages,
muſt ſteel the Souldier; his own ſhame help to arm him;
and having forc'd his ſpirit, ere he cools,
fling him upon his enemies; ſudden and ſwift,
like Tygers amongſt Foxes, we muſt fight for 't:
Fury muſt be our Fortune; ſhame we have loſt,
ſpurs ever in our ſides to prick us forward:
there is no other wiſedom nor diſcretion
due to this day of ruine, but deſtruction;
the Souldiers order firſt, and then his anger.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: No doubt they dare redeem all.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Then no doubt
the day muſt needs be ours. That the proud woman
is infinite in number, better likes me,
then if we dealt with ſquadrons: half her Army
ſhall choke themſelves, their own ſwords dig their graves.
I'll tell ye all my fears, one ſingle valour,
the vertues of the valiant Caratach
more doubts me then all Britain: he's a Souldier
ſo forg'd out, and ſo temper'd for great fortunes,
ſo much man thruſt into him, ſo old in dangers,
ſo fortunate in all attempts, that his meer name
fights in a thouſand men, himſelf in millions,
to make him Romane. But no more. Petillius,
how ſtands your charge?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Ready for all employments,
to be commanded too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: 'T is well govern'd;
to morrow we'll draw out, and view the Cohorts:
i' th' mean time, all apply their Offices.
Where's Junius?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: In 's Cabbin,
ſick o' th' mumps, Sir.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.p: In love, indeed in love, moſt lamentably loving, to the tune of Queen Dido.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Alas poor Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: 'T will make him fight the nobler. With what Lady?
I'll be a ſpokeſman for him.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: You'll ſcant ſpeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Who is 't?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: The devils dam, Bonduca's daughter,
her youngeſt, crackt i' th' ring.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: I am ſorry for him:
but ſure his own diſcretion will reclaim him,
he muſt deſerve our anger elſe. Good Captains,
apply your ſelves in all the pleaſing forms
ye can, unto the Souldiers; fire their ſpirits,
and ſet 'em fit to run this action;
mine own proviſion ſhall be ſhar'd amongſt 'em,
till more come in: tell 'em, if now they conquer,
the fat of all the kingdom lies before 'em,
their ſhames forgot, their honours infinite,
and want for ever baniſht. Two days hence,
our fortunes, and our ſwords, and gods be for us. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I muſt come?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: So the General commands, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I muſt bring up my Regiment?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Believe, Sir,
I bring no lye.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: But did he ſay, I muſt come?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: So delivered.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: How long is 't, Regulus, ſince I commanded
in Britain here?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: About five yeers, great Penyus.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The General ſome five months. Are all my actions
ſo poor, and loſt, my ſervices ſo barren,
that I 'm remembred in no nobler language
but Muſt come up?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I do beſeech ye, Sir,
weigh but the times eſtate.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Yes, good Lievtenant,
I do, and his that ſways it. Muſt come up?
Am I turn'd bare Centurion? Muſt, and ſhall,
fit embaſſes to court my honour?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Sir—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Set me to lead a handful of my men
againſt an hundred thouſand barbarous ſlaves
that have marcht name by name with Romes beſt doers?
ſerve 'em up ſome other meat; I'll bring no food
to ſtop the jaws of all thoſe hungry wolfs.
My Regiment 's mine own. I muſt, my language.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Penyus, where lies the hoſt?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Where Fate may finde 'em.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Are they ingirt?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The Battel's loſt.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: So ſoon?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: No; but 't is loſt, becauſe it muſt be won:
the Britains muſt be Victors. Who ere ſaw
a troop of bloody Vultures hovering
about a few corrupted carcaſes,
let him behold the ſilly Romane hoſt,
girded with millions of fierce Britain Swains,
with deaths as many as they have had hopes;
and then go thither, he that loves his ſhame;
I ſcorn my life, yet dare not loſe my name.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Do not you hold i● a moſt famous end,
when both our names and lives are ſacrific'd
for Romes encreaſe?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Yes, Curius; but mark this too;
what glory is there, of what laſting fame
can be to Rome, or us? what full example,
when one is ſmother'd with a multitude,
and crowded in amongſt a nameleſſe preſſe?
Honour got out of flint, and on their heads
whoſe vertues, like the Sun, exhal'd all valours,
muſt not be loſt in miſts and fogs of people,
noteleſſe, and out of name, but rude and naked:
nor can Rome task us with impoſſibilities,
or bid us fight againſt a flood: we ſerve her,
that ſhe may proudly ſay ſhe has good ſouldiers,
nor ſlaves to choke all hazards. Who but fools,
that make no difference betwixt certain dying,
and dying well, would fling their fames and fortunes
into this Britain-gulf, this quickſand-ruine,
that ſinking, ſwallows us? What noble hand
can finde a ſubject fit for blood there? or what ſword
room for his execution? What air to cool us,
but poiſon'd with their blaſting breaths and curſes,
where we lie buried quick above the ground,
and are with labouring ſweat, and breathleſſe pain,
kill'd like to ſlaves, and cannot kill again?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: Penyus, mark ancient Wars, and know that then Captains weigh'd an hundred thouſand men.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Druſius, mark ancient wiſdom, and you'll finde then
he gave the overthrow that ſav'd his men.
I muſt not go.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: The ſouldiers are deſirous,
their Eagles all drawn out, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Who drew up. Regulus?
ha? ſpeak: did you? whoſe bold will durſt attempt this?
drawn out? why, who commands, Sir? on whoſe warrant
durſt they advance?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I keep mine own obedience.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: 'T is like the general cauſe, their love of honour, relieving of their wants.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Without my knowledge?
am I no more? my place but at their pleaſures?
Come, who did this?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: By— Sir, I am ignorant.

div.stage: Drum ſoftly within: then enter Souldiers with Drum and Colours.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: What, am I grown a ſhadow? Heark, they march.
I will know, and will be my ſelf. Stand, diſobedience;
he that advances one foot higher, dies for 't.
Run thorow the Regiment upon your duties,
and charge 'em on command: beat back again,
by—I'll tith'em all elſe.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: We'll do our beſt.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Back; ceaſe your bawling Drums there,
I'll beat the Tubs about your brains elſe. Back:
do I ſpeak with leſſe fear then Thunder to ye?
muſt I ſtand to beſeech ye? home, home: ha?
do ye ſtare upon me? Are thoſe mindes I moulded,
thoſe honeſt valiant tempers I was proud
to be a fellow to, thoſe great diſcretions
made your names fear'd and honour'd, turn'd to wildfires?
O gods, to diſobedience? Command, farewel;
and be ye witneſſe with me, all things ſacred,
I have no ſhare in theſe mens ſhames. March, Souldiers,
and ſeek your own ſad ruines; your old Penyus
dares not behold your murders.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.l: Captain.

sp.speaker: 3 Sould.
sp.l: Dear honour'd Captain●

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Too too dear lov'd Souldiers,
which made ye weary of me: and heaven yet knows,
though in your mutinies, I dare not hate you;
Take your own wills; 't is fit your long experience
ſhould now know how to rule your ſelves: I wrong ye,
in wiſhing ye to ſave your lives and credits,
to keep your necks whole from the Ax hangs ore ye:
alas, I much diſhonour'd ye: go, ſeek the Britains,
and ſay ye come to glut their Sacrifices;
but do not ſay I ſent ye. What ye have been,
how excellent in all parts, good, and govern'd,
is onely left of my Command, for ſtory;
what now ye are, for pitie. Fare ye well.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: Oh turn again, great Penyus; ſee the Souldier in all points apt for duty.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: See his ſorrow
for his diſobedience, which he ſays was haſte,
and haſte (he thought) to pleaſe you with. See, Captain,
the toughneſſe of his courage turn'd to water;
ſee how his manly heart melts.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Go, beat homeward,
there learn to eat your little with obedience,
and henceforth ſtrive to do as I direct ye.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: My anſwer, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Tell the great General,
my Companies are no fagots to fill breaches;
my ſelf no man that muſt, or ſhall, can carry:
bid him be wiſe; and where he is, he 's ſafe then;
and when he findes out poſſibilities,
he may command me. Commend me to the Captains.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: All this I ſhall deliver.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Farewel, Macer. Exit Penyus.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Pray gods this breed no miſchief.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: It muſt needs,
if ſtout Swetonius win; for then his anger,
beſides the Souldiers loſſe of due, and honour,
will break together on him.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: He's a brave fellow;
and but a little hide his haughtineſſe,
(which is but ſometimes neither, on ſome cauſes)
he ſhews the worthieſt Romane this day living.
You may, good Curius, to the General
make all things ſeem the beſt.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I ſhall endeavour:
pray for our fortunes, Gentlemen. If we fall,
this one farewel ſerves for a Funeral.
The gods make ſharp our ſwords, and ſteel our hearts;
we dare, alas, but cannot fight our parts.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Junius, Petillius and a Herald.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Let him go on: ſtay, now he talks.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Why?
why ſhould I love mine enemie? what is beauty?
of what ſtrange violence, that like the plague,
it works upon our ſpirits? blind they faign him,
I am ſure, I find it ſo.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: A dog ſhall lead ye.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: His fond affections blinder.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Hold ye there ſtill.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: It takes away my ſleep,

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Alas, poor chicken.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: my company, content; almoſt my faſhion.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Yes, and your weight too, if you follow it.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: 'Tis ſure the plague, for no man dare come neer me without an Antidote: 'tis far worſe; Hell.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Thou art damn'd without redemption then.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: The way to 't
ſtrew'd with fair Weſtern ſmiles, and April bluſhes,
led by the brighteſt conſtellations; eyes,
and ſweet proportions, envying heaven: but from thence
no way to guide, no path, no wiſdome brings us.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Yes, a ſmart water, Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Do I fool?
know all this, and fool ſtill? Do I know further,
that when we have enjoy'd our ends, we loſe 'em,
and all our appetites are but as dreams
wee laugh at in our ages.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: Sweet Philoſopher!

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Do I know on ſtill, and yet know nothing? Mer|cie gods,
why am I thus ridiculous?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Motley on thee,
thou art an arrant Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Can red and white,
an eye, a noſe, a cheek,

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: But one cheek, Junius?
an half-fac'd Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: with a little trim,
that wanton fools call Faſhion, thus abuſe mee?
take me beyond my reaſon? Why ſhould not I
doat on my horſe well trapt, my ſword well hatch'd?
they are as handſom things, to mee more uſefull,
and poſſible to rule too. Did I but love,
yet 'twere excuſable, my youth would bear it;
but to love there, and that no time can give me,
mine honour dare not ask: ſhee has been raviſh'd
my nature, muſt not know; ſhe hates our Nation.
Thus to diſpoſe my ſpirit!

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Stay a little,
he will declame again.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I will not love; I am a man, have reaſon,
and I will uſe it: I'll no more tormenting,
nor whining for a wench, there are a thouſand,

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Hold thee there boy.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: A thouſand will intreat me.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Ten thouſand, Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am young and luſtie,
and to my faſhion valiant; can pleaſe nightly.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I'll ſwear thy back's probatum, for I have known thee
leap at ſixteen like a ſtrong Stallion.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I will be man again.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Now mark the working,
the divell and the ſpirit tug for't: twenty pound
upon the divels head.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I muſt be wretched.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I knew I had won.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Nor have I ſo much power
to ſhun my fortune.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I will hunt thy fortune
with all the ſhapes imagination breeds, Muſick.
but I will fright thy divell: S●ay, he ſings now.

div.stage: Song, by Junius, and Petillius after him in mockage.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Muſt I be thus abuſ'd?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Yes mary muſt ye.
Let's follow him cloſe: oh, there he is, now read it.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: It is the Generals command, that all ſick, perſons old and unable, retire within the Trenches; hee that fears his libertie, to leave the Field: Fools, boyes, and lovers must not come neer the Regiments, for fear of their infecti|ons; eſpecially thoſe Cowards they call Lovers.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Hah?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Read on.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.p: If any common Souldier love an Enemie, hee's whip'd and made a ſlave: If any Captain; caſt, with loſſe of honours, flung out o'th' Army, and made unable ever after to bear the name of a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: The — conſume ye all, Rogues. Exit Jun.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Let this work:
h'as ſomething now to chew upon: he's gone,
come, ſhake no more.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Well, Sir, you may command me,
but not to doe the like again for Europe:
I would have given my life for a bent two-pence.
If I ere read to lovers whilſt I live again,
or come within their confines —

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: There's your payment,
and keep this private.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I am ſchool'd for talking. Exit Herald.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: How now, Demetrius, are we drawn?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis doing:
Your Company ſtands fair; but pray ye, where's Junius?
half his command are wanting, with ſome forty
that Decius leads.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Hunting for victuals:
upon my life free-booting Rogues, their ſtomacks
are like a widows luſt, nere ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I wonder how they dare ſtir, knowing the enemy
Maſter of all the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Reſolute hungers
know neither fears, nor faiths, they tread on ladders,
ropes, gallowes, and overdoe all dangers.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: They may be hang'd though.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: There's their joyfull ſupper,
and no doubt they are at it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: But for heavens ſake,
how does young Junius?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Drawing on, poor Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: What, to his end?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: To th'end of all fl●ſh: woman.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: This Love has made him a ſtout ſouldier.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: O, a great one,
fit to command young goſlings: but what news?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I think the meſſenger's come back from Penyus by this time, let's go know.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: What will you ſay now
if he deny to come, and take exceptions
at ſome half ſyllable, or ſound deliverd
with an ill accent, or ſome ſtile left out?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I cannot think he dare.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: He dare ſpeak treaſon,
dare ſay, what no man dares beleeve, dares doe—
but that's all one: I'll lay you my black armour
to twenty crowns, he comes not.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Done.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: You'll pay.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Then keep thine old uſe Penyus,
be ſtubborn and vain glorious, and I thank thee.
Come let's go pray for ſix hours: moſt of us
I fear, will trouble heaven no more: two good blowes
ſtruck home at two Commanders of the Britains,
and my part's done.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I do not think of dying.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: 'Tis poſſible we may live. But Demetrius,
with what ſtrange legs, and arms, and eyes, and noſes,
let Carpenters and Copper-ſmiths conſider.
If I can keep my heart whole, and my wind-pipe,
that I may drink yet like a Souldier —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Come, let's have better thoughts; mine's on your Armour.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: Mine's in your purſe, Sir: Let's go try the wager.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Judas and his four Companions (halters about their necks) Bonduca, her Daughters, Nennius following.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Come, hang 'm preſently.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: What made your Rogueſhips
harrying for victuals here? Are we your friends?
or doe you come for Spies? tell me directly,
Would you not willingly be hang'd now? do not ye long for't?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: What ſay ye? ſhall wee hang in this vain? Hang we muſt,
and 'tis as good to diſpatch it merrily,
as pull an arſe like dogs to't.

sp.speaker: 1. Soul.
sp.l: Any way,
ſo it be handſome.

sp.speaker: 3. Soul.
sp.p: I had as lief 'twere toothſom too: but all agree, and I'll not out Boyes.

sp.speaker: 4. Soul.
sp.l: Let's hang pleſantly.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Then pleſantly be it: Captain, the truth is,
we had as lief hang with meat in our mouthes,
as ask your pardon empty.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Theſe are brave hungers.
What ſay you to a leg of Beef now, ſirha?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Bring me acquainted with it, and I'll tell ye.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Torment 'em wenches: I muſt back; then hang 'em.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: We humbly thank your Grace.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: The Rogues laugh at us.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: Sirha, What think you of a wench now?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: A wench, Lady?
I do beſeech your Ladiſhip, retire,
I'll tell ye preſently, ye ſee the time's ſhort;
one craſh; even to the ſetling of my conſcience.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Why, is't no more but up, boyes?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Yes, ride too Captain.
Will you but ſee my ſeat?

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: Ye ſhall be ſet, Sir,
upon a Jade ſhall ſhake ye.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Sheets, good Madam,
will do it ten times better.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: Whips, good Souldier,
which ye ſhall taſte before ye hang, to mortifie ye;
'tis pitie ye ſhould die thus deſperate.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: Theſe are the merry Romans, the brave mad-caps.
'tis ten to one wee'll cool your reſolutions.
Bring out the whips.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Would your good Ladyſhips
would exerciſe 'em too.

sp.speaker: 4. Soul.
sp.l: Surely Ladies,
we'ld ſhew you a ſtrange patience.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Hang 'em, Raſcals,
they'l talk thus on the wheel. Enter Caratach.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Now what's the matter?
What are theſe fellows? whats the crime committed,
that they wear necklaces?

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: They are Roman Rogues,
taken a forraging.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Is that all, Nennius?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Would I were fairly hang'd; this is the divell,
the kill-cow Caratach.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And you would hang 'em.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Are they not enemies?

sp.speaker: 1. Soul.
sp.l: My breech makes buttons.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: Are they not our tormentors?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Tormentors? Flea-traps.
Pluck off your halters, fellows.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Take heed, Caratach,
taint not your wiſdome.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Wiſdome, Nennius?
why, who ſhall fight againſt us, make our honours,
and give a glorious day into our hands,
if we diſpatch our foes thus? what's their offence?
ſtealing a loafe or two to keep out hunger,
a piece of greazie bacon, or a pudding?
do theſe deſerve the gallows? They are hungry,
poor hungry knaves, no meat at home left, ſtarv'd:
Art thou not hungry?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Monſtrous hungry.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: He looks like hungers ſelf: get 'em ſome victuals, and wine to cheer their hearts, quick: Hang up poor pil|chers?

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: This is the braveſt Captain —

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: I'll leave you to your will.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I'll anſwer all, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: Let's up, and view his entertainment of 'em.
I am glad they are ſhifted any way, their tongues elſe
would ſtill have murdred us.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: Let's up, and ſee it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Sit down poor knaves: why, where's this wine
and victuals?
who waites there?

sp.speaker: Suit. within.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis coming.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Who are theſe Uncle?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: They are Romans, Boy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Are theſe they
that vex mine Aunt ſo? can theſe fight? they look
like emptie ſcabbards, all, no mettle in 'em,
like men of clouts, ſet to keep crows from orchards;
why, I dare fight with theſe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That's my good chicken. And how do ye?
how do you feel your ſtomacks?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Wondrous apt, Sir,
as ſhall appear when time calls.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That's wel, down with't,
a little grace will ſerve your turns: eat ſoftly,
you'll choak ye knaves elſe: give 'em wine.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Not yet, Sir,
we're even a little buſie.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Can that fellow
do any thing but eat? thou fellow.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Away Boy,
away, this is no boyes play.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: By —, Uncle,
if his valour lie in's teeth, he's the moſt valiant.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am glad to hear ye talk, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Good Uncle tell me,
What's the price of a couple of cramm'd Romans?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Some twenty Britains boy; theſe are good ſoldiers,

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Do not the cowards eat hard too?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No more, boy.
Come, I'll ſit with you too; ſit down by me, boy.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Pray bring your diſh then.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Hearty knaves: More meat there.

sp.speaker: 1. Soul.
sp.l: That's a good hearing.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Stay now and pledge me.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: This little piece Sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: By — ſquare eaters,
More meat I ſay: upon my conſcience
the poor Rogues have not eat this month: how terribly
they charge upon their victuals: dare ye fight thus?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Beleeve it ſir, like devils.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Wel ſaid famine,
Here's to thy General.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Moſt excellent Captain, I wil now pledge thee.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And to morrow night, ſay to him,
His head is mine.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: I can aſſure ye Captain,
He wil not give it for this waſhing.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Wel ſaid. Daughters above.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: Here's a ſtrange entertainment: how the theeves drink.

sp.speaker: 2. Daug.
sp.l: Danger is dry, they look'd for colder liquor.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Fil'em more wine, give 'em ful bowls; which of you all now
in recompence of this good, dare but give me
a ſound knock in the Battell?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Delicate Captain,
to doe thee a ſufficient recompence,
I'll knock thy brains out.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Do it.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Thou dar'ſt as well be damn'd: thou knock his brains out,
thou skin of man? Uncle, I will not hear this.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Tie up your whelp.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Thou kill my Uncle?
Would I had but a ſword for thy ſake, thou dry'd dog.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What a mettle
this little vermine caries.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Kill mine Uncle?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: He ſhall not, child.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: He cannot: he's a Rogue,
an onely eating Rogue: Kill my ſweet Uncle?
oh that I were a man.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: By this wine,
which I will drink to Captain Junius,
who loves the Queens moſt excellent Majeſties little daughter
moſt ſweetly, and moſt fearfully, I will do it.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Uncle, I'll kill him with a great pin.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No more, Boy.
I'll pledge thy Captain: To ye all, good Fellows.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: In love with me? that love ſhall coſt your lives all:
Come Siſter, and adviſe me; I have here
a way to make an eaſie conqueſt of 'em,
if fortune favour me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Let's ſee ye ſweat
to morrow, blood and ſpirit, Boyes, this wine
turn'd to ſterne valour.

sp.speaker: 1. Soul.
sp.l: Heark ye Judas,
if he ſhould hang us after all this.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Let him:
I'll hang like a Gentleman, and a Roman.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Take away there,
they have enough.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Captain, wee thank you heartily
for your good cheer, and if we meet to morrow,
one of us payes for't.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Get 'em guides, their wine Enter 2^d Daughter and a Servant.
has over maſter'd 'em.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: That hungry fellow
with the red beard there, give it him, and this,
to ſee it well deliverd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Farewell, knaves;
ſpeak nobly of us, keep your words to morrow,
and doe ſomething worthy your meat. Go, guide 'em,
and ſee 'em fairly onward.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Meaning me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: The ſame.
The youngeſt daughter to the Queen intreats ye
to give this privately to Captain Junius,
this for your pains.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: I reſt her humble ſervant.
Commend me to thy Lady. Keep your files, boyes.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: I muſt inſtruct ye farther.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Keep your files there.
Order, ſweet friends: faces about now.

sp.speaker: Guide.
sp.l: Here Sir,
here lies your way.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: 'Bleſſe the founders, I ſay.
Fairly, good ſouldiers, fairly march now: cloſe, boyes.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Swetonius, Petillius, Demetrius, Decius, Macer.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Bid me be wiſe, and keep me where I am,
and ſo be ſafe: not come, becauſe commanded;
Was it not thus?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: It was, Sir.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: What now think ye?

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.p: Muſt come, ſo hainous to him, ſo diſtaſtefull?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Give me my money.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: I confeſſe 'tis due Sir,
and preſently I'll pay it.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: His obedience
ſo blind at his yeers and experience,
it cannot find where to be tendred?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Sir,
the Regiment was willing, and advanc'd too,
the Captains at all points ſteel'd up; their preparations
full of reſolve, and confidence; Youth and fire,
like the fair breaking of a glorious day,
guilded their Falanx: when the angrie Penyus
ſtept like a ſtormy cloud 'twixt them and hopes.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: And ſtopt their reſolutions?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: True: his reaſon
to them was ods, and ods ſo infinite,
diſcretion durſt not look upon.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Well Penyus,
I cannot think thee coward yet; and treacherous
I dare not think: thou haſt lopt a limb off from me,
and let it be thy glory, thou waſt ſtubborn,
thy wiſdome, that thou leftſt thy Generall naked:
Yet ere the Sun ſet, I ſhall make thee ſee,
all valour dwels not in thee; all command
in one experience. Thou wilt too late repent this,
and wiſh, I muſt come up, had been thy bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Let's force him.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: No, by no means; he's a torrent
we cannot eaſily ſtemme.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I think, a Traitor.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: No il words: let his own ſhame firſt revile him.
That wine I have, ſee it (Demetrius)
diſtributed amongſt the ſouldiers,
to make 'em high and luſtie: when that's done,
Petillius, give the word through, that the Eagles
may preſently advance: no man diſcover,
upon his life, the enemies full ſtrength,
but make it of no value: Decius,
are your ſtarv'd people yet come home?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: I hope ſo.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Keep 'em in more obedience: This is no time
to chide, I could be angry elſe, and ſay more to ye:
But come, let's order all: whoſe ſword is ſharpeſt,
and valour equall to his ſword this day,
ſhall be my ſaint.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: We ſhall be holy all then. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Captain, Captain, I have brought 'em off again;
the drunkeneſt ſlaves.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: — confound your Rogueſhips;
I'll call the Generall, and have ye hang'd all.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Pray who will you command then?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: For you, ſirha,
that are the ring-leader to theſe deviſes,
whoſe maw is never cramm'd, I'll have an engine.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: A wench, ſweet Captain.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Sweet Judas, even the Forks.
where ye ſhall have two Lictors with two whips
hammer your hide.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Captain, good words, fair words,
ſweet words, good Captain; if you like not us,
farewell, we have imployment.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Where haſt thou been?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: There where you dare not be with all your valour.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Where's that?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: With the beſt good-fellow living.

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.l: The king of all good-fellows.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Shake now, and ſay, wee have done ſomething worthie,
mark me; with Caratach: By this — Caratach:
Do you aſmuch now and you dare: ſweet Caratach.
Ye talk of a good fellow, of true drinking;
wel, go thy waies, old Caratach: beſides the drink Captain,
the braveſt running banquet of black puddings,
peeces of glorious beef.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: How ſcapt ye hanging?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Hanging's a dogs death: we are Gentlemen,
and I ſay ſtill, Old Caratach.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Belike then,
you are turn'd Rebels all.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: We are Roman boyes all,
and boyes of mettle: I muſt doe that Captain,
this day, this very day.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Away, ye Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Fair words, I ſay again.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: What muſt you doe, Sir?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: I muſt do that my heart-ſtrings yern to do:
but my word's paſt.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Why, kill Caratach.
that's all he ask'd us for our entertainment.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: More then you'll pay.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Would I had ſold my ſelf
unto the skin, I had not promiſ'd it:
for ſuch another Caratach.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Come Fool,
have ye done your Country ſervice?

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: I have brought that
to Captain Iunius.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: I think will doe all:
I cannot tell, I think ſo.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: How? to Iunius?
I'll more enquire of this: You'll fight now?

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Promiſe:
take heed of promiſe, Captain.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Away, and rank then.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: But heark ye Captain, there is wine diſtributing,
I would fain know what ſhare I have.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Be gone,
ye have too much.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Captain, no wine, no fighting.
there's one call'd Caratach, that has wine.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Well Sir,
if you'll be rul'd now, and doe well.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Doe excellent.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Ye ſhall have wine, or any thing: goe file;
I'll ſee ye have your ſhare: drag out your dormiſe,
and ſtow 'em ſomwhere, where they may ſleep handſomly,
they'l hear a hunt's up ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Now I love thee:
but no more Forks nor Whips.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Deſerve 'em not then:
up with your men, I'll meet ye preſently;
and get 'em ſober quickly.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Arm, arm, Bullyes;
all's right again and ſtraight; and which is more,
more wine, more wine: Awake ye men of Memphis,
be ſober and diſcreet, we have much to do boyes. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Prepare there for the Sacrifice, the Queen comes.

div.stage: Enter in Solemnity, the Druids ſinging, the ſecond Daughter ſtrewing flowers: then Bonduca, Caratach, Nennius, and others.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Ye powerfull gods of Britain, hear our prayers;
hear us you great Revengers, and this day
take pitie from our ſwords, doubt from our valours,
double the ſad remembrance of our wrongs
in every breſt; the vengeance due to thoſe
make infinite and endleſſe: on our pikes
this day pale terror ſit, horrors and ruines
upon our executions; claps of thunder
hang on our armed carts, and 'fore our Troops
deſpair and death; ſhame beyond theſe attend 'em.
Riſe from the duſt, ye relicks of the dead,
whoſe noble deeds our holy Druids ſing,
oh riſe, ye valiant bones, let not baſe earth
oppreſſe your honours, whileſt the pride of Rome
treads on your Stocks, and wipes out all your ſtories.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Thou great Tiranes, whom our ſacred Prieſts,
armed with dreadfull thunder, place on high
above the reſt of the immortall gods,
ſend thy conſuming fires and deadly bolts,
and ſhoot 'em home; ſtick in each Roman heart
a fear fit for confuſion; blaſt their ſpirits,
dwell in 'em to deſtruction; thorow their Phalanx
ſtrike, as thou ſtrik'ſt a proud tree; ſhake their Bodies,
make their ſtrengths totter, and their topleſſe fortunes
unroot, and reel to ruine.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: O thou god,
thou feared god, if ever to thy juſtice
inſulting wrongs, and raviſhments of women,
women deriv'd from thee, their ſhames, the ſuffrings
of thoſe that daily fill'd thy Sacrifice
with virgin incenſe, have acceſſe, now hear me,
now ſnatch thy thunder up, now on theſe Romans,
deſpiſers of thy power, of us defacers,
revenge thy ſelf: take to thy killing anger,
to make thy great work full, thy juſtice ſpoken,
an utter rooting from this bleſſed Iſle
of what Rome is or has been.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Give more incenſe,
the gods are deafe and drowſie; no happy flame
riſes to raiſe our thoughts: Pour on.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: See heaven,
and all you pow'rs that guide us, ſee, and ſhame
we kneel ſo long for pitie over your Altars;
ſince 'tis no light oblation that you look for,
no incenſe offring, will I hang mine eyes;
and as I wear theſe ſtones with hourly weeping,
ſo will I melt your pow'rs into compaſſion.
This tear for Proſutagus my brave Father,
ye gods, now think on Rome; this for my Mother,
and all her miſeries; yet ſee, and ſave us:
but now ye muſt be open ey'd. See, heaven,
O ſee thy ſhowrs ſtoln from thee; our diſhonours,
O ſiſter, our diſhonours: can ye be gods,
and theſe ſins ſmother'd?

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: The fire takes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: It does ſo,
but no flame riſes. Ceaſe your fetrfull prayers,
your whinings, and your tame petitions;
the gods love courage arm'd with confidence,
and prayers fit to pull them down: weak tears
and troubled hearts, the dull twins of cold ſpirits,
they ſit and ſmile at. Hear how I ſalute 'em:
Divine Audate, thou who hold'ſt the reins
of furious Battels, and diſordred War,
and proudly roll'ſt thy ſwarty chariot wheels
over the heaps of wounds, and carcaſſes,
ſailing through ſeas of bloud; thou ſure-ſteel'd ſternneſſe,
give us this day good hearts, good enemies,
good blowes o' both ſides, wounds that fear or flight
can claim no ſhare in; ſteel us both with angers,
and warlike executions fit thy viewing;
let Rome put on her beſt ſtrength, and thy Britain,
thy little Britain, but as great in fortune,
meet her as ſtrong as ſhee, as proud, as daring;
and then look on, thou red ey'd god: who does beſt,
reward with honour; who deſpair makes flie,
unarme for ever, and brand with infamie:
Grant this, divine Audate, 't is but Juſtice;
and my firſt blow thus on thy holy Altar A flame ariſes.
I ſacrifiſe unto thee.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: It flames out. Muſick.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Now ſing ye Druides. Song.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: 'Tis out again.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: H'as given us leave to fight yet; we ask no more,
the reſt hangs in our reſolutions:
tempt him no more.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: I would know further Coſen,

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: His hidden meaning dwels in our endeavours;
our valours are our beſt gods. Cheer the ſouldier,
and let him eat.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: He's at it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Away then;
when he has done, let's march. Come, fear not Lady,
this day the Roman gains no more ground here,
but what his body lies in.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Now I am confident. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: We dare not hazzard it: beſide our lives,
it forfeits all our underſtandings.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
Can ye forſake me in ſo juſt a ſervice,
a ſervice for the Common-wealth, for honour?
Read but the Letter; you may love too.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Read it:
if there be any ſafety in the circumſtance,
or likelihood 'tis love, we will not faile ye.
Read it good Curius.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Willingly.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Now mark it.

sp.speaker: Cur. reads.
sp.l: Health to thy heart, my honourd Junius,
and all thy love requited: I am thine,
thine everlaſtingly, thy love has won me,
and let it breed no doubt; our new acquaintance
compels this, 'tis the gods decree to bleſſe us.
The times are dangerous to meet; yet fail not,
by all the love thou bear'ſt me I conjure thee,
without diſtruſt of danger, to come to me,
for I have purpoſ'd a delivery
both of my ſelf and fortune this bleſt day
into thy hands, if thou thinkſt good: to ſhew thee
how infinite my love is, even my Mother
ſhall be thy priſoner, the day yours without hazzard;
for I beheld your danger like a Lover,
a juſt affecter of thy faith: Thy goodneſſe,
I know, will uſe us nobly, and our marriage,
if not redeem, yet leſſen Romes Ambition.
I am weary of theſe miſeries: Uſe my Mother,
(if you intend to take her) with all honour,
and let this diſobedience to my parents
be laid on love, not me. Bring with thee, Junius,
ſpirits reſolv'd to fetch me off, the nobleſt,
forty will ſerve the turn; juſt at the joyning
of both the Battels, we will be weakly guarded;
and for a guide, within this hour ſhall reach thee
a faithfull friend of mine: the gods, my Junius,
keep thee, and me to ſerve thee: Young Bonvica.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: This letter carries much belief, and moſt objections
anſwer'd, we muſt have doubted.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Is that fellow
come to ye for a guide yet?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: And examin'd?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Far more then that; he has felt tortures, yet
he vows he knows no more then this truth.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Strange.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: If ſhe mean what ſhe writes, as 't may be probable,
'twill be the happieſt vantage we can lean to.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I'll pawn my ſoul ſhe means truth.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Think an hour more,
then if your confidence grow ſtronger on ye,
we'll ſet in with ye.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Nobly done; I thank ye;
ye know the time.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: We will be either ready
to give ye preſent counſell, or joyne with ye.

div.stage: Enter Swetonius, Petillius, and Demetrius, Macer.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: No more as ye are Gentlemen. The Generall.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Draw out a pace, the enemy waits for us;
Are ye all ready?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: All our Troops attend, Sir.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: I am glad to hear you ſay ſo, Junius.
I hope ye are diſpoſſeſt.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I hope ſo too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Continue ſo. And Gentlemen, to you now;
To bid you fight is needleſſe, ye are Romans,
the name will fight it ſelf; To tell ye who
you go to fight againſt, his power, and nature,
but loſſe of time: ye know it, know it poor,
and oft have made it ſo. To tell ye further,
his Bodie ſhowes more dreadfull then it has done,
to him that fears, leſſe poſſible to deal with,
is but to ſtick more honour on your Actions,
load ye with vertuous names, and to your memories
tie never dying time, and fortune conſtant.
Go on in full aſſurance, draw your ſwords
as daring and as confident as Juſtice;
the gods of Rome fight for ye; loud Fame calls ye,
pitch'd on the topleſſe Perinine, and blows
to all the under world: all Nations,
the ſeas, and unfrequented deſerts, where the ſnow dwels,
wakens the ruin'd monuments, and there
where nothing but eternall death and ſleep is,
informs again the dead bones. With your vertues,
go on, I ſay, valiant and wiſe, rule heaven,
and all the great aſpects attend 'em. Do but blow
upon this Enemy, who, but that we want foes,
cannot deſerve that name; and like a myſt,
a lazie fog, before your burning valours
you'll finde him flie to nothing. This is all,
We have ſwords, and are the ſons of ancient Romans,
heirs to their endleſſe valours, fight and conquer.

sp.speaker: De. Dem.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: That man that loves not this day,
and hugs not in his arms the noble danger,
may he die fameleſſe and forgot.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Sufficient,
up to your Troops, and let your drums beat thunder,
march cloſe, and ſudden like a tempeſt: all executions
done without ſparkling of the Body: keep your phalanx
ſure lin'd, and piec'd together; your pikes forward,
and ſo march like a moving Fort: ere this day run,
we ſhal have ground to add to Rome, wel won. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena tertia.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: The Roman is advanc'd from yound' hils brow,
we may behold him, Caratach. A March.

div.stage: Drums within at one place afar off.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Let's thither,
I ſee the duſt flie. Now I ſee the Body,
obſerve 'em, Nennius; by — a handſome Body,
and of a few, ſtrongly and wiſely joynted
Swetonius is a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: As I take it,
that's hee that gallops by the Regiments,
viewing their preparations.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Very likely,
he ſhews no leſſe then Generall: ſee how bravely
the Body moves, and in the head how proudly
the Captains ſtick like plumes: hee comes apace on;
good Nennius go, and bid my ſtout Leutenant
bring on the firſt ſquare Bodie to oppoſe 'em,
and as he charges, open to encloſe 'em:
the Queen move next with hers, and wheel about,
to gain their backs, in which I'll lead the Vantguard.
We ſhall have bloody crowns this day, I ſee by 't;
Haſte thee good Nennius, I'll follow inſtantly.
How cloſe they march, as if they grew together? March.
no place but lin'd alike: ſure from oppreſſion;
they will not change this figure: we muſt charge 'em,
and charge 'em home at both ends, Van and Rere,
sp.stage: Drums in another place afar off.
sp.l: they never totter elſe. I hear our Muſick,
and muſt attend it: Hold good ſword, but this day,
and bite hard where I hound thee, and hereafter
I'll make a relique of thee, for young Souldiers
to come like Pilgrimes to, and kiſſe for Conqueſts.

div.head: Scaena quarta.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Now is the time, the fellow ſtayes.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: What think yee?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I think 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Alas, if 'twere a queſtion,
if any doubt or hazzard fell into 't,
do ye think mine own diſcretion ſo ſelf-blinde,
my care of you ſo naked, to run headlong?

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Let's take Petillius with us.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: By no means:
hee's never wiſe but to himſelf, nor courteous,
but where the end's his own: we are ſtrong enough,
if not too many. Behind yonder hill
the fellow tels me ſhe attends, weak guarded,
her Mother and her Siſter.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I would venture.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Wee ſhall not ſtrike five blows for't: weigh the good,
the generall good may come.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Away, I'll with ye,
but with what doubt?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Fear not, my ſoul for all. Exeunt.

div.stage: Alarms, Drums and Trumpets in ſeverall places afar off, as at a main Battell.

div.head: Scaena quinta.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Here ye may ſee 'em all, Sir; from this hill
the Country ſhews off levell.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Gods defend me,
what multitudes they are, what infinites?
the Roman power ſhews like a little Star
hedg'd with a double halloa. Now the knell rings,
Heark how they ſhout to th' battell; how the air
totters and reels, and rends apieces, Druſus,
with the huge vollied clamours.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Now they charge.
oh gods, of all ſides, fearfully.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Little Rome,
ſtand but this growing Hydra one ſhort hour,
and thou haſt out-done Hercules.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: The duſt hides 'em,
we cannot ſee what follows.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: They are gone,
gone, ſwallow'd, Druſus; this eternall Sun
ſhall never ſee 'em march more.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: O turn this way,
and ſee a modell of the field, ſome forty,
againſt four hundred.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Well fought, bravely follow'd;
O nobly charg'd again, charg'd home too: Druſus,
they ſeem to carry it: now they charge all, Loud.
cloſe, cloſe, I ſay; they follow it: ye gods,
Can there be more in men? more daring ſpirits?
ſtil they make good their fortunes. Now they are gone too,
for ever gone: ſee Druſus, at their backs
a fearfull Ambuſh riſes. Farewell valours,
excellent valours: O Rome, Where's thy wiſdome?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: They are gone indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Look out toward the Army,
I am heavie with theſe ſlaughters.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: 'Tis the ſame ſtill,
cover'd with duſt and fury. Enter the two Daughters, with Junius, Curius, Decius, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: Bring 'em in,
tie 'em, and then unarm 'em.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: Valiant Romans,
ye are welcome to your Loves,

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: Your death, fools.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: We deſerve 'em,
and women do your worſt.

sp.speaker: 1. Daug.
sp.l: Ye need not beg it.

sp.speaker: 2. Daug.
sp.l: Which is kinde Junius?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: This.

sp.speaker: 2 Dau.
sp.l: Are you my ſweet heart?
It looks ill on't: how long is 't, pretty ſoul,
ſince you and I firſt lov'd? Had we not reaſon
to doat extreamly upon one another?
How does my Love? this is not he: my chicken
could prate finely, ſing a love-ſong.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Monſter.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: Oh, now it courts.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Arm'd with more malice
then he that got thee has the divell.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: Good.
Proceed, ſweet Chick.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I hate thee, that's my laſt.

sp.speaker: 2. Daug.
sp.l: Nay, and ye love me, forward: No? Come ſiſter,
let's prick our anſwers on our arrows points,
and make 'em laugh a little. Ye damn'd Leachers,
ye proud improvident fools, have we now caught ye?
are ye i'th'nooſe? Since ye are ſuch loving creatures,
wee'll be your Cupids: Do ye ſee theſe arrows?
wee'll ſend 'em to your wanton livers, goats.

sp.speaker: 1. Dau.
sp.l: O how I'll trample on your hearts, ye villains,
ambitious ſalt-itcht ſlaves: Romes maſter ſins,
the mountain Rams topt your hot mothers.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: Dogs,
to whoſe brave Founders a ſalt whore gave ſuck;
theeves, honours hangmen, do ye grin? perdition
take me for ever, if in my fell anger, Enter Caratach.
I doe not out-doe all example.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Where,
where are theſe Ladies? ye keep noble quarter,
your mother thinks ye dead or taken; upon which,
ſhe will not move her Battell. Sure theſe faces
I have beheld and known, they are Roman Leaders,
How came they here?

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: A trick Sir, that we uſ'd,
a certain policie conducted 'em
unto our ſnare: we have done ye no ſmall ſervice;
theſe uſ'd as we intend, we are for th' battell.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: As you intend? taken by treachery?

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: Is't not allow'd?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thoſe that ſhould gild our Conqueſt,
make up a Battell worthie of our winning,
catch'd up by craft?

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: By any means that's lawfull.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: A womans wiſdome in our triumphs? Out,
out ye ſluts, ye follies; from our ſwords
filch our revenges baſely? Arm again, Gentlemen:
Souldiers, I charge ye help 'em.

sp.speaker: 2. Daugh.
sp.l: By — Uncle,
we will have vengeance for our rapes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: By —
you ſhould have kept your legs cloſe then: diſpatch there.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: I will not off thus.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: He that ſtirs to execute,
or ſhe, though it be your ſelves, by him that got me,
ſhall quickly feel mine anger: one great day given us,
not to be ſnatch'd out of our hands but baſely;
and muſt we ſhame the gods from whence we have it,
with ſetting ſnares for Souldiers? I'll run away firſt,
be hooted at, and children call me coward,
before I ſet up ſcales for Victories:
Give 'em their ſwords.

sp.speaker: 2. Daug.
sp.l: O gods.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Bear off the women
unto their Mother.

sp.speaker: 2. Daug.
sp.l: One ſhot, gentle Uncle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: One cut her fiddle-ſtring: Beat'em off I ſay.

sp.speaker: 1. Dau.
sp.l: The — take this fortune.

sp.speaker: Cara.
sp.l: Learn to ſpin,
and curſe your knotted hemp: goe Gentlemen,
ſafely go off, up to your troops: be wiſer,
there thank me like tall Souldiers: I ſhall ſeek ye.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: A noble worth.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Well Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Pray ye no more.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: He bluſhes, do not load him.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Where's your love now? Drums loud again.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Puffe, there it flies: Come, let's redeem our follies.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Awake, Sir; yet the Roman Bodie's whole,
I ſee 'em cleer again.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Whole? 'tis not poſſible:
Druſus, they muſt be loſt.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: By — they are whole, Sir,
and in brave doing; ſee, they wheel about
to gain more ground.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: But ſee there Druſus, ſee,
ſee that huge Battell moving from the mountains,
their gilt coats ſhine like Dragons ſcales, their march
like a rough tumbling ſtorm; ſee them, and view 'em,
and then ſee Rome no more: ſay they faile; look,
look where the armed carts ſtand; a new Army:
look how they hang like falling rocks, as murdring
death rides in triumph Druſus: fell deſtruction
laſhes his fiery horſe, and round about him
his many thouſand wayes to let out ſoules.
Move me again when they charge, when the mountain
melts under their hot wheels, and from their Ax'trees
huge claps of thunder plough the ground before 'em,
till then I'll dream what Rome was.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: O bravely fought; honour till now nere ſhow'd
her golden face i'th' field. Like lions, Gentlemen,
y' have held your heads up this day: Where's yong Junius,
Curius, and Decius?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Gone to heaven, I think, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.l: Their worths go with 'em: breath a while: How do ye?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Wel; ſome few ſcurvie wounds, my heart's whole yet.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Would they would give us more ground.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Give? wee'll have it.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Have it? and hold it too, deſpight the divell.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: Lead up to th' head, and line ſure: the Qs. Battell begins to charge like wild-fire: Where's the Generall?

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Oh, they are living yet. Come, my brave ſouldiers,
come, let me powr Romes bleſſing on ye; Live,
live, and lead Armies all: ye bleed hard.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Beſt:
wee ſh●ll appear the ſterner to the foe.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: More wounds, more honour.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Loſe no time.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Away then,
and ſtand this ſhock, ye have ſtood the world.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Wee'll grow to't.
Is not this better now then lowſie loving?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am my ſelf, Petillius.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: 'Tis I love thee. Exeunt Romans.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Charge 'em i'th' flanks: O ye have plaid the fool, the fool extremely, the mad fool.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.l: Why Coſin?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: The woman fool. Why did you give the word
unto the carts to charge down, and our people
in groſſe before the Enemie? we pay for't,
our own ſwords cut our throats: why? — on't,
Why do you offer to command? the divell,
the divell, and his dam too, who bid you
meddle in mens affairs? Exeunt Queen, &c.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: I'll help all.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Home,
home and ſpin woman, ſpin, go ſpin, ye trifle.
Open before there, or all's ruine. How, Showts within.
now comes the tempeſt; on our ſelves, by—
O woman, ſcurvie woman, beaſtly woman. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: How's that, Druſus?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.p: They win, they win, they win; oh look, look, look, Sir, for heavens ſake look, the Britains fly, the Britains fly. Vi|ctoria. Enter Swetonius, Souldiers, and Captains.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Soft, ſoft, purſue it ſoft; excellent Souldiers,
cloſe, my brave fellows, honourable Romans:
oh cool thy mettle Junius, they are ours,
the world cannot redeem 'em: ſtern Petillius,
govern the conqueſt nobly: ſoft, good Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Shame, whither flie ye, ye unluckie Britains?
Will ye creep into your mothers wombs again? Back cowards,
Hares, fearfull Hares, Doves in your angers; leave me?
leave your Queen deſolate? her hapleſſe children
to Roman rape again and fury?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Flie, ye buzzards,
ye have wings enough, ye fear: get thee gone, woman,
ſhame tread upon thy heels: all's loſt, all's loſt, heark,
heark how the Romans ring our knels. Ext. Bond. &c.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Good Uncle,
let me go too.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No boy, thy fortune's mine,
I muſt not leave thee; get behind me; ſhake not,
I'll breech ye, if ye do boy: Come, brave Romans,
all is not loſt yet.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: Now I'll thank thee, Caratach. Fight. Drums.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou art a Souldier: ſtrike home, home; have at ye.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: His blows fall like huge ſledges on an anvil.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: I am weary.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: So am I.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Send more ſwords to me.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Let's ſit and reſt. Sit down.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: What think ye now?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: O Druſus,
I have loſt mine honour, loſt my name,
loſt all that was my light: theſe are true Romans,
and I a Britain coward, a baſe coward;
guide me where nothing is but deſolation,
that I may never more behold the face
of man, or mankind know me: O blind Fortune,
haſt thou abuſ'd me thus?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Good Sir, be comforted;
it was your wiſdome rul'd ye; pray ye go home,
your day is yet to come, when this great fortune
ſhall be but foile unto it. Retreat.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Fool, fool, Coward. Exit Penyus & Druſus.

div.stage: Enter Swetonius, Demetrius, Souldiers, Drum and Colours.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Draw in, draw in: wel have ye fought, and worthie
Romes noble recompence; look to your wounds,
the ground is cold and hurtfull: the proud Queen
has got a Fort, and there ſhe and her Daughters
defie us once again. To morrow morning
wee'll ſeek her out, and make her know, our Fortunes
ſtop at no ſtubborn walls: Come, ſons of honour,
true vertues heirs; thus hatch'd with Britain blood,
let's us march to reſt, and ſet in gules like Suns.
Beat a ſoft march, and each one eaſe his neighbours.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Petillius, Junius, Decius, Demetrius ſinging.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Smooth was his cheek,

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: And his chin it was ſleek,

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: With whoop, he has done wooing.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Junius was this Captains name,
A lad for a laſſes viewing,

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Ful black his eye, & plump his thigh.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Made up for loves purſuing:

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Smooth was his cheek,

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And his chin it was ſleek.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: With whoop, he has done wooing.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: O my vex'd thief, art thou come home again?
are thy brains perfect?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Sound as bels.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Thy back-worm
quiet, and caſt his ſting, boy?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Dead, Petillius,
dead to all folly, and now my anger only.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Why, that's wel ſaid: hang Cupid and his quiver,
a drunken brawling Boy; thy honour'd ſaint
be thy ten ſhillings, Junius; there's the money,
and there's the ware; ſquare dealing: this but ſweats thee
like a neſh nag, and makes thee look pin buttock'd;
the other runs thee whining up and down
like a pig in a ſtorm, fils thy brains full of ballads,
and ſhews thee like a long Lent, thy brave body
turn'd to a tail of green-fiſh without butter.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: When thou lov'ſt next, love a good cup of wine,
a Miſtris for a King, ſhe leaps to kiſſe thee,
her red and white's her own; ſhe makes good blood,
takes none away; what ſhee heats ſleep can help,
without a groping Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am counſell'd,
and henceforth, when I doat again, —

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Take heed,
ye had almoſt paid for't.
