sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: Love no more great Ladies,
thou canſt not ſtep amiſſe then; there's no delight in 'em;
all's in the whiſtling of their ſnatcht up ſilks;
they're onely made for handſome view, not handling;
their bodies of ſo weak and waſh a temper,
a rough-pac'd bed will ſhake 'em all to pieces;
a tough hen puls their teeth out, tyres their ſouls;
plenae rimarum ſunt, they are full of rynnet,
and take the skin off where they are taſted; ſhun 'em,
they live in culliſſes like rotten cocks
ſtew'd to a tenderneſſe, that holds no tack:
Give me a thing I may cruſh.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Thou ſpeak'ſt truly:
the Warres ſhall be my Miſtris now.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: Well choſen,
for ſhe's a bownſing laſſe, ſhe'll kiſſe thee at night, boy,
and break thy pate i'th' morning.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Yeſterday
I found thoſe favours infinite.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Wench good enough,
but that ſhe talks too loud.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: She talks to th' purpoſe,
which never woman did yet: ſhee'll hold grapling,
and he that layes on beſt, is her beſt ſervant:
all other loves are meer catching of dotrels,
ſtretching of legs out onely, and trim lazineſſe. Enter
Here comes the Generall. Swet. Curius & Macer.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: I am glad I have found ye:
Are thoſe come in yet that purſu'd bold Caratach?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Not yet Sir, for I think they mean to lodge him;
take him I know they dare not, 'twill be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Then haſte Petillius, haſte to Penyus,
I fear the ſtrong conceit of what diſgrace
h'as pull'd upon himſelf, will be his ruine:
I fear his ſouldiers fury too; haſte preſently,
I would not loſe him for all Britain. Give him, Petillius,

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: That that ſhall choak him.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: all the noble counſell,
his fault forgiven too, his place, his honour,

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: For me, I think, as handſome.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: all the comfort;
and tell the Souldier, 'twas on our command
hee drew not to the Battell.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: I conceive Sir,
and will doe that ſhall cure all.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Bring him with ye
before the Queens Fort, and his Forces with him,
there you ſhall find us following of our Conqueſt:
Make haſte.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: The beſt I may. Exit.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: And noble Gentlemen,
Up to your Companies: wee'll preſently
upon the Queens purſuit: There's nothing done
till ſhe be ſeiz'd; without her nothing won. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: How does my Boy?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I would doe well, my heart's well;
I doe not fear.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My good boy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I know, Uncle,
we muſt all die; my little brother dy'd,
I ſaw him die, and he dy'd ſmiling: ſure,
there's no great pain in't Uncle. But pray tell me,
Whither muſt we goe when we are dead?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Strange queſtions!
why, to the bleſſed'ſt place Boy: ever ſweetneſſe
and happineſſe dwels there.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Will you come to me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Yes, my ſweet boy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Mine Aunt too, and my Coſins?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: All, my good childe.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: No Romans, Uncle?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No, boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: I ſhould be loth to meet them there.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No ill men,
that live by violence, and ſtrong oppreſſion,
come thither: 't is for thoſe the gods love, good men.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Why, then I care not when I go; for ſurely
I am perſwaded they love me: I never
blaſphem'd 'em, Uncle, nor tranſgreſt my parents;
I always ſaid my prayers.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt go, then,
indeed thou ſhalt.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: When they pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That's my good boy.
Art thou not weary, Hengo?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Weary, Uncle?
I have heard you ſay you have march'd all day in Armour.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I have, boy.

sp.speaker: Hengo.
sp.l: Am not I your kinſman?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: And am not I as fully alli'd unto you
in thoſe brave things, as blood?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou art too tender.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: To go upon my legs? they were made to bear me:
I can play twenty mile a day; I ſee no reaſon
but, to preſerve my Countrey and my ſelf,
I ſhould march fourty.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What, wouldſt thou be
living to wear a mans ſtrength?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Why a Caratach,
a Romane-hater, a ſcourge ſent from heaven Drum.
to whip theſe proud theeves from our kingdom. Heark,
heark, Uncle, heark, I hear a Drum.

div.stage: Enter Judas and his people to the door.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Beat ſoftly,
ſoftly, I ſay; they are here: who dare charge?

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.l: He
that dares be knockt o' th' head: I'll not come neer him.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Retire again, and watch then. How he ſtares!
h' as eyes would kill a dragon: mark the boy well;
if we could take or kill him. A — on ye,
how fierce ye look? ſee how he broods the boy;
the devil dwells in's ſcabbard. Back, I ſay,
apace, apace, h' as found us. They retire.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Do ye hunt us?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Uncle, good Uncle ſee, the thin ſtarv'd Raſcal,
the eating Romane, ſee where he thrids the thickets:
kill him, dear Uncle, kill him; one good blow
to knock his brains into his breech: ſtrike's head off,
that I may piſſe in 's face.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Do ye make us Foxes?
Here, hold my charging-ſtaff, and keep the place, boy.
I am at bay, and like a bull I'll bear me.
Stand, ſtand, ye Rogues, ye Squirrels. Exit.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Now he pays 'em:
O that I had a mans ſtrength.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Here's the boy;
mine own, I thank my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Uncle, uncle;
famine is faln upon me, uncle.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Come, Sir,
yeeld willingly, your uncle 's out of hearing;
I'll tickle your young tail elſe.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: I defie thee,
thou mock-made man of mat: charge home, ſitha:
hang thee, baſe ſlave, thou ſhakeſt.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Upon my conſcience
the boy will beat me: how it looks, how bravely,
how confident the worm is: a ſcabb'd boy
to handle me thus? yeeld, or I cut thy head off.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Thou dar'ſt not cut my finger: here 't is, touch it.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: The boy ſpeaks ſword and buckler. Prethee yeeld, boy:
come, here 's an apple; yeeld.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: By— he fears me.
I'll give you ſharper language: When, ye coward,
when come ye up?

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: If he ſhould beat me—

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: When, Sir?
I long to kill thee; come, thou canſt not ſcape me,
I have twenty ways to charge thee; twenty deaths
attend my bloody ſtaff.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Sure 't is the devil,
a dwarf, devil in a doubler.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.p: I have kill'd a Captain, ſirha, a brave Captain, and when I have done. I have kickt him thus. Look here, ſee how I charge this ſtaff.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: Moſt certain
this boy will cut my throat, yet.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.l: Flee, flee, he kills us.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.l: He comes, he comes.

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: The devil take the hindmoſt.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Run, run, ye Rogues, ye precious Rogues, ye rank Rogues.
A comes, a comes, a comes, a comes: that 's he, boys.
What a brave cry they make?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: How does my chicken?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: 'Faith, uncle, grown a Souldier, a great Souldier;
for by the vertue of your charging-ſtaff,
and a ſtrange fighting face I put upon 't,
I have outbrav'd hunger.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That's my boy, my ſweet boy.
Here, here's a Romane 's head for thee.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Good proviſion.
Before I ſtarve, my ſweet-fac'd Gentleman,
I'll trie your favour.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: A right compleat ſouldier.
Come, chicken, let's go ſeek ſome place of ſtrength
(the Countrey 's full of Scouts) to reſt a while in,
thou wilt not elſe be able to endure.
The journey to my Countrey, fruits, and water,
muſt be your food a while, boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Any thing:
I can eat moſſe, nay, I can live on anger,
to vex theſe Romanes. Let 's be wary, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I warrant thee; come chearfully.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: And boldly. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: The ſouldier ſhall not grieve ye.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Pray ye forſake me;
look not upon me, as ye love your Honours;
I am ſo cold a coward, my infection
will choke your vertues like a damp elſe.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Dear Captain.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Moſt honour'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Moſt hated, moſt abhor'd;
ſay ſo, and then ye know me, nay, ye pleaſe me.
O my dear credit, my dear credit.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Sure
his minde is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: The good gods cure it.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: My honour got thorow fire, thorow ſtubborn, breaches
thorow battels that have been as hard to win as heaven,
thorow death himſelf, in all his horrid trims,
is gone for ever, ever, ever, Gentlemen,
and now I am left to ſcornful tales and laughters,
to hootings at, pointing with fingers, That's he,
that's the brave Gentleman forſook the battel,
the moſt wiſe Penyus, the diſputing coward.
O my good ſword, break from my ſide, and kill me;
cut out the coward from my heart.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Ye are none.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: He lyes that ſays ſo: by— he lyes, lyes baſely,
baſer then I have done. Come, ſouldiers, ſeek me,
I have robb'd ye of your vertues: Juſtice, ſeek me,
I have broke my fair obedience, loſt: ſhame take me,
take me, and ſwallow me, make ballads of me;
ſhame, endleſſe ſhame: and pray do you forſake me.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: What ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Good Gentlemen forſake me:
you were not wont to be commanded. Friends, pray do it,
and do not fear; for as I am a coward
I will not hurt my ſelf: when that minde takes me,
I'll call to you, and ask your help. I dare not.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Good morrow, Gentlemen; where's the Tribune?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Whence come ye, good Petillius?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: From the General.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: With what, for heavens ſake?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: With good counſel, Druſus,
and love, to comfort him.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Good Regulus
ſtep to the ſouldier, and allay his anger;
for he is wilde as winter.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: O, are ye there? have at ye. Sure he 's dead,
it cannot be he dare out live this fortune:
he muſt die, 't is moſt neceſſary; men expect it;
and thought of life in him, goes beyond coward.
Forſake the field ſo baſely? fie upon 't:
ſo poorly to betray his worth? ſo coldly
to cut all credit from the ſouldier? ſure
if this man mean to live, as I ſhould think it
beyond belief, he muſt retire where never
the name of Rome, the voice of Arms, or Honour
was known or heard of yet: he 's certain dead,
or ſtrongly means it; he 's no Souldier elſe,
no Romane in him; all he has done, but outſide,
fought either drunk or deſperate. Now he riſes.
How does Lord Penyus?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: As ye ſee.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I am glad on 't;
continue ſo ſtill. The Lord General,
the valiant General, great Swetonius—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: No more of me is ſpoken; my name's periſh'd.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: He that commanded fortune and the day
by his own valour and diſcretion,
when, as ſome ſay, Penyus refuſed to come,
but I believe 'em not, ſent me to ſee ye.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Ye are welcom; and pray ſee me; ſee me well,
ye ſhall not ſee me long.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I hope ſo, Penyus;
the gods defend, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: See me, and underſtand me: This is he
lef● to fill up your triumph; he that baſely
whiſtled his honour off to th' winde; that coldly
ſhrunk in his politick head, when Rome like reapers
ſweat blood, and ſpirit, for a glorious harveſt,
and bound it up, and brought it off: that fool,
that having gold and cupper offer'd him,
refus'd the wealth, and took the waſte: that ſouldier
that being courted by loud fame and fortune,
labour in one hand, that propounds us gods,
and in the other, glory that creats us,
yet durſt doubt, and be damned.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: It was an errour.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A foul one, and a black one.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Yet the blackeſt
may be waſht white again.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Your leave, Sir,
and I beſeech ye note me; for I love ye,
and bring along all comfort: Are we gods,
alli'd to no infirmities? are our natures
more then mens natures? when we ſlip a little
out of the way of vertue, are we loſt?
is there no medicine called Sweet mercie?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: None, Petillius;
there is no mercie in mankinde can reach me,
nor is it fit it ſhould; I have ſinn'd beyond it.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Forgiveneſſe meets with all faults.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: 'T is all faults,
all ſins I can commit, to be forgiven:
't is loſſe of whole man in me, my diſcretion
to be ſo ſtupid, to arrive at pardon.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: O but the General—

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: He's a brave Gentleman,
a valiant, and a loving; and I dare ſay
he would, as far as honour durſt direct him,
make even with my fault: but 't is not honeſt,
nor in his power: examples that may nouriſh
neglect and diſobedience in whole bodies,
and totter the eſtates and faiths of armies,
muſt not be plaid withal; nor out of pitie
make a General forget his duty:
nor dare I hope more from him then is worthy.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: What would ye do?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Die.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: So would ſullen children,
women that want their wils, ſlaves, diſobedient,
that fear the law, die. Fie, great Captain; you
a man to rule men, to have thouſand lives
under your regiment, and let your paſſion
betray your reaſon? I bring you all forgiveneſſe,
the nobleſt kinde commends, your place, your honour.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Prethee no more; 't is fooliſh: didſt not thou?
by — thou didſt, I over-heard thee, there,
there where thou ſtandſt now, deliver me for raſcal,
poor, dead, cold coward, miſerable, wretched,
if I out-liv'd this ruine?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: And thou didſt it nobly,
like a true man, a ſouldier: and I thank thee,
I thank thee, good Petillius; thus I thank thee.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Since ye are ſo juſtly made up, let me tell ye
'tis fit ye die indeed.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: O how thou loveſt me!

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: For ſay he had forgiven ye; ſay the peoples whiſpers
were tame again, the time run out for wonder,
what muſt your own Command think, from whoſe Swords
ye have taken off the edges, from whoſe valours
the due and recompence of Arms; nay, made it doubtful
whether they knew obedience? muſt not theſe kill ye?
Say they are won to pardon ye, by meer miracle
brought to forgive ye; what old valiant Souldier,
what man that loves to fight, and fight for Rome,
will ever follow you more? dare ye know theſe ventures?
if ſo, I bring ye comfort; dare ye take it?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: No, no, Petillius, no.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: If your minde ſerve ye,
ye may live ſtill; but how? yet pardon me,
you may outwear all too; but when? and certain
there is a mercy for each fault, if tamely
a man will take 't upon conditions.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: No, by no means: I am onely thinking now, Sir,
(for I am reſolved to go) of a moſt baſe death,
fitting the baſeneſſe of my fault. I'll hang,

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Ye ſhall not; y' are a Gentleman I honour,
I would elſe flatter ye, and force ye live,
which is far baſer. Hanging? 't is a dogs death,
an end for ſlaves.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: The fitter for my baſeneſſe.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.p: Beſides, the man that 's hang'd, preaches his end, and ſits a ſigne for all the world to gape at.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: That's true: I'll take a fitter poiſon.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: No,
't is equal ill; the death of rats, and women,
lovers, and lazie boys, that fear correction.
Die like a man.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Why my ſword then.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I, if your ſword be ſharp, Sir,
there 's nothing under heaven that 's like your ſword;
your ſword 's a death indeed.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſharp, Sir.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Why Mithridates was an arrant aſſe
to die by poiſon, if all Boſphorus
could lend him ſwords: your ſword muſt do the deed:
't is ſhame to die choak'd, fame to die and bleed.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Thou haſt: confirmed me: and, my good Petillius,
tell me no more I may live.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: 'T was my Commiſſion;
but now I ſee ye in a nobler way,
a way to make all even.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Fare-well, Captain:
be a good man, and fight well: be obedient:
command thy ſelf, and then thy men. Why ſhakeſt thou?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I do not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I would thou hadſt, Petillius:
I would finde ſomething to forſake the world with
worthy the man that dies: a kinde of earth-quake
thorow all ſtern valours but mine own.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I feel now
a kinde of trembling in me.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Keep it ſtill,
as thou lov'ſt vertue, keep it.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And brave Captain,
the great and honoured Penyus.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: That again:
O how it heightens me! again, Petillius.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Moſt excellent Commander.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Thoſe were mine,
mine, onely mine.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: They are ſtill.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Then to keep 'em
for ever falling more, have at ye, heavens,
ye everlaſting powers, I am yours: The work's done,
that neither fire, nor age, nor melting envie
ſhall ever conquer. Carry my laſt words
to the great General: kiſſe his hands, and ſay,
My ſoul I give to heaven, my fault to juſtice
which I have done upon my ſelf: my vertue,
if ever there was any in poor Penyus,
made more, and happier, light on him. I faint.
And where there is a foe, I wiſh him fortune.
I die: lie lightly on my aſhes, gentle earth.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And on my ſin. Fare-well, great Penyus,
the ſouldier is in fury. Now I am glad
't is done before he comes. This way, for me,
the way of toil; for thee, the way of honour. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Druſus and Regulus, with ſouldiers.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: Kill him, kill him, kill him.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: What will ye do?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Good ſouldiers, honeſt ſouldiers.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: Kill him, kill him, kill him.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Kill us firſt; we command too.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Valiant Souldiers,
conſider but whoſe life ye ſeek. O Druſus,
bid him be gone, he dies elſe. Shall Rome ſay
(ye moſt approved ſouldiers) her dear children
devoured the fathers of the fights? ſhall rage
and ſtubborn fury guide thoſe ſwords to ſlaughter,
to ſlaughter of their own, to Civil ruine?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: O let 'em in: all 's done, all 's ended, Regulus,
Penyus has found his laſt eclipſe. Come, Souldiers,
come, and behold your miſeries: come bravely,
full of your mutinous and bloody angers,
and here beſtow your darts. O onely Romane,
O father of the Wars.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Why ſtand ye ſtupid?
where be your killing furies? whoſe ſword now
ſhall firſt be ſheath'd in Penyus? do ye weep?
Howl out, ye wretches, ye have cauſe: howl ever.
Who ſhall now lead ye fortunate? whoſe valour
preſerve ye to the glory of your Countrey?
who ſhall march out before ye, coy'd and courted
by all the miſtriſſes of War, care, counſel,
quick-ey'd experience, and victory twin'd to him?
who ſhall beget ye deeds beyond inheritance
to ſpeak your names, and keep your honours living,
when children fail, and time that takes all with him,
build houſes for ye to oblivion?

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: O ye poor deſperate fools: no more now, ſouldiers;
go home, and hang your arms up; let iuſt rot'em;
and humble your ſtern valours to ſoft prayers;
for ye have ſunk the frame of all your vertues;
the ſun that warm'd your bloods is ſet for ever:
I'll kiſſe thy honour'd cheek. Fare well, great Penyus,
thou thunder-bolt, fare-well. Take up the body:
to morrow morning to the Camp convey it.
there to receive due Ceremonies. That eye
that blindes himſelf with weeping, gets moſt glory.

div.head: Scaena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Swetonius, Junius, Decius, Demetrius, Curius, and Souldiers: Bonduca, two daughters, and Nennius, above. Drum and Colours.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Bring up the Catapults and ſhake the wall,
we will not be out-brav'd thus.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Shake the earth,
ye cannot ſhake our ſouls. Bring up your Rams,
and with their armed heads, make the Fort totter,
ye do but rock us into death. Exit Nennius.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: See Sir,
ſee the Icenian Queen in all her glory
from the ſtrong battlements proudly appearing,
as if ſhe meant to give us laſhes.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Yeeld, Queen.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: I am unacquainted with that language, Roman.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Yeeld, honour'd Lady, and expect our mercie,
we love thy nobleneſſe.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: I thank ye, ye ſay well;
but mercie and love are ſins in Rome and hell.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Ye cannot ſcape our ſtrength; ye muſt yeeld, Ladie,
ye muſt adore and fear the power of Rome.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: If Rome be earthly, why ſhould any knee
with bending adoration worſhip her?
She's vitious; and your partiall ſelves confeſſe,
aſpires the height of all impietie:
therefore 'tis fitter I ſhould reverence
the thatched houſes where the Britains dwell
in careleſſe mirth, where the bleſt houſhold gods
ſee nought but chaſte and ſimple puritie.
'Tis not high power that makes a place divine,
nor that the men from gods derive their line.
But ſacred thoughts in holy boſoms ſtor'd,
make people noble, and the place ador'd.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Beat the wall deeper.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Beat it to the center,
we will not ſink one thought.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: I'll make ye.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: 2. Dan.
sp.l: O mother, theſe are fearfull hours: ſpeak gently
to theſe fierce men, they will afford ye pitie.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Pitie? thou fearful girl; 'tis for thoſe wretches
that miſerie makes tame. Wouleſt thou live leſſe?
Waſt not thou born a Princeſſe? Can my blood,
and thy brave fathers ſpirit, ſuffer in thee
ſo baſe a ſeparation from thy ſelf,
as mercie from theſe Tyrants? Thou lov'ſt luſt ſure,
and long'ſt to proſtitute thy youth and beautie
to common ſlaves for bread. Say th y had mercie;
the divel a relenting conſcience:
the lives of Kings reſt in their Diadems,
which to their bodies lively ſouls do give,
and ceaſing to be Kings, they ceaſe to live.
Show ſuch another fear, and —
I'll fling thee to their furie.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: He is dead then?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I think ſo certainly; yet all my means, Sir,
even to the hazzard of my life —

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: No more:
wee muſt not ſeem to mourn here.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: There's a breach made,
is it your will we charge, Sir?

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Once more mercie,
mercie to all that yeeld.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: I ſcorn to anſwer:
Speak to him girle; and hear thy ſiſter.

sp.speaker: 1. Daugh.
sp.l: Generall,
hear me, and mark me well, and look upon me
directly in my face, my womans face,
whoſe onely beautie is the hate it bears ye;
ſee with thy narroweſt eyes, thy ſharpeſt wiſhes,
into my ſoul, and ſee what there inhabits;
ſee if one fear, one ſhadow of a terrour,
one paleneſſe dare appear but from my anger,
to lay hold on your mercies. No, ye fools,
poor Fortunes fools, we were not born for triumphs,
to follow your gay ſports, and fill your ſlaves
with hoots and acclamations.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Brave behaviour.

sp.speaker: 1 Daugh.
sp.l: The children of as great as Rome, as noble,
our names before her, and our deeds her envie;
muſt we gild ore your Conqu ſt, make your State,
that is not fairly ſtrong, but fortunate?
No, no, ye Romanes, we have ways to ſcape ye,
to make yee poor again, indeed our priſoners,
and ſtick our triumphs full.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: 's death, I ſhall love her.

sp.speaker: 1 Daugh.
sp.l: To torture ye with ſuff●ring, like our ſlaves;
to make ye curſe our patience, wiſh the world
were loſt again, to win us onely, and eſteem
the end of all ambitions.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Do ye wonder?
we'll make our monuments in ſpite of fortune,
in ſpight of all your E gles wings: we'll work
a pitch above ye; and from our height we'll ſtoop
as fearleſſe of your bloody fears; and fortunate,
as if we prey'd on heartleſſe doves.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Strange ſtiffneſſe.
Decius, go charge the breach. Exit Decius.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Charge it home, Romane,
we ſhall deceive thee elſe. Where 's Nennius?

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: They have made a mighty breach.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Stick in thy body,
and make it good but half an hour.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: I'll do it.

sp.speaker: 1 Daugh.
sp.l: And then be ſure to die.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: It ſhall go hard elſe.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Fare well with all my heart; we ſhall meet yonder,
where few of theſe muſt come.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Gods take thee, Lady.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Bring up the ſwords, and poiſon.

div.stage: Enter one with ſwords, and a great cup.

sp.speaker: 2 Daugh.
sp.l: O my fortune!

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: How, how, ye whore?

sp.speaker: 2 Daugh.
sp.l: Good mother, nothing to offend ye.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Here, wench:
behold us, Romanes.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Mercy yet.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: No talking:
puff; there goes all your pitie. Come, ſhort prayers,
and let 's diſpatch the buſineſſe: you begin,
ſhrink not; I'll ſee ye do 't.

sp.speaker: 2 Daugh.
sp.l: O gentle mother,
O Romanes, O my heart; I dare not.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Woman, woman,
unnatural woman.

sp.speaker: 2 Daugh.
sp.l: O perſwade her, Romanes:
alas, I am young, and would live. Noble mother,
can ye kill that ye gave life? are my yeers
fit for deſtruction?

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Yeeld, and be a Queen ſtill,
a mother, and a friend.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Ye talk: come, hold it,
and put it home.

sp.speaker: 1 Daugh.
sp.l: Fie, ſiſter, fie,
what would you live to be?

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: A whore ſtill.

sp.speaker: 2 Daugh.
sp.l: Mercie.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Hear her, thou wretched woman.

sp.speaker: 2 Daugh.
sp.l: Mercie, mother:
O whither will you ſend me? I was once
your darling, your delight.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: O gods,
fear in my family? do it, and nobly.

sp.speaker: 2 Daugh.
sp.l: O do not frown then.

sp.speaker: 1 Daugh.
sp.l: Do it, worthy ſiſter:
't is nothing, 't is a pleaſure; we'll go with ye.

sp.speaker: 2 Daugh.
sp.l: O if I knew but whither.

sp.speaker: 1 Daugh.
sp.l: To the bleſſed,
where we ſhall meet our father.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Woman.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Talk not.

sp.speaker: 1 Daugh.
sp.l: Where nothing but true joy is.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.p: That 's a good wench, mine own ſweet girl; put it cloſe to thee.

sp.speaker: 2 Daugh.
sp.l: O comfort me ſtill, for heavens ſake.

sp.speaker: 1 Daugh.
sp.l: Where eternal
our youths are, and our beauties; where no Wars come,
nor luſtful ſlaves to raviſh us.

sp.speaker: 2 Daugh.
sp.l: That ſteels me:
a long farewel to this world.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Good: I'll help thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Daugh.
sp.l: The next is mine.
Shew me a Romane Lady in all your ſtories,
dare do this for her honour: they are cowards,
eat coals like compell'd Cats: your great Saint Lucrece
di'd not for honour; Tarquin topt her well,
and mad ſhe could not hold him, bled.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: By—
I am in love: I would give an hundred pound now
but to lie with this womans behaviour. O the devil.

sp.speaker: 1 Daugh.
sp.l: Ye ſhall ſee me example. All your Rome,
if I were proud, and lov'd ambition;
if I were luſtful, all your ways of pleaſure;
if I were greedie, all the wealth ye conquer—

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: Make haſte.

sp.speaker: 1 Daugh.
sp.l: I will. Could not intice to live
but two ſhort hours this frailty: would ye learn
how to die bravely, Romanes, to fling off
this caſe of fleſh, loſe all your cares for ever?
live as we have done, well, and fear the gods,
hunt Honour, and not Nations with your ſwords,
keep your mindes humble, your devotions high;
ſo ſhall ye learn the nobleſt part, to die.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: I come, wench; to ye all Fates hang-men; you
that caſe the aged deſtinies, and cut
the threds of Kingdoms, as they draw 'em: here,
here 's a draught would ask no leſſe then Caeſar
to pledge it for the glories ſake.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Great Lady.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Make up your own conditions.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: So we will.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Be any thing.

sp.speaker: Bond.
sp.l: A Saint, Swetonius,
when thou ſhalt fear, and die like a ſlave. Ye foole,
ye ſhould have ti'd up, death firſt, when ye conquer'd,
ye ſweat for us in vain elſe: ſee him here,
he 's ours ſtill, and our friend; laughs at your pities;
and we command him with as eaſie reins
as do our enemies. I feel the poiſon.
Poor vanquiſh'd Romanes, with what matchleſſe tortures
could I now rack ye? But I pitie ye,
deſiring to die quiet: nay, ſo much
I hate to proſecute my victory,
that I will give ye counſel ere I die.
If you will keep your Laws and Empire whole,
place in your Romane fleſh a Britain ſoul.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Deſperate and ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: 'T is won, Sir, and the Britains
all put to th' ſword.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Give her fair Funeral;
ſhe was truely noble, and a Queen.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: —take it,
a love-mange grown upon me? what, a ſpirit?

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: I am glad of this, I have found ye.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: In my belly,
O how it tumbles?

sp.speaker: Iun.
sp.l: Ye good gods, I thank ye. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Caratach upon a rock, and Hengo by him, ſleeping.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thus we afflicted Britains climb for ſafeties,
and to avoid our dangers, ſeek deſtructions;
thus we awake to ſorrows. O thou woman,
thou agent for adverſities, what curſes
this day belong to thy improvidence?
to Britanie by thy means, what ſad millions
of widows weeping eyes? The ſtrong mans valour
thou haſt betraid to fury; the childes fortune
to fear, and want of friends: whoſe pieties
might wipe his mournings off, and build his ſorrows
a houſe of reſt by his bleſt anceſtore:
the virgins thou haſt rob'd of all their wiſhes,
blaſted their blowing hopes, turn'd their ſongs,
their mirthful Marriage ſongs to Funerals,
the Land thou haſt left a wilderneſſe of wretches.
The boy begins to ſtir: thy ſafety made,
would my ſoul were in heaven.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: O noble Uncle,
look out; I dream'd we were betraid.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No harm, boy;
't is but thy emptineſſe that breeds theſe fancies;
thou ſhalt have meat anon.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: A little, Uncle,
and I ſhall hold out bravely. What are thoſe?
look, Uncle, look, thoſe multiutdes that march there?
they come upon us ſtealing by.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I ſee 'em;
and prethee be not fearful.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Now ye hate me,
would I were dead.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou know'ſt I love thee dearly.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Did I ere ſhrink yet, Uncle? were I a man now,
I ſhould be angry with ye.

div.stage: Enter Druſus, Regulus, and Souldiers, with Penyus Herſe, Drums and Colours.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My ſweet chicken,
ſee, they have reach'd us, and as it ſeems they bear
ſome Souldiers body, by their ſolemn geſtures,
and ſad ſolemnities; it well appears too
to be of eminence. Moſt worthy Souldiers,
let me intreat your knowledge to inform me
what noble body that is which you bear
with ſuch a ſad and ceremonious grief,
as if ye meant to woo the world and nature
to be in love with death? Moſt honourable
excellent Romanes, by your ancient valours,
as ye love fame, reſolve me.

sp.speaker: Sould.
sp.l: 'T is the body
of the great Captain Penyus, by himſelf
made cold and ſpiritleſſe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O ſtay, ye Romanes,
by the religion which you owe thoſe gods
that lead ye on to Victories, by thoſe glories
which made even pride a vertue in ye.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Stay:
what 's thy will, Caratach?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Set down the body,
the body of the nobleſt of all Romanes,
as ye expect an offering at your graves
from your friends ſorrows, ſet it down a while,
that with your griefs an enemy may mingle;
a noble enemy that loves a Souldier;
and lend a tear to vertue: even your foes,
your wild foes, as you call'd us, are yet ſtor'd
with fair affections, our hearts freſh, our ſpirits,
though ſometimes ſtubborn, yet when vertue dies,
ſoft and relenting as a virgins prayers.
O ſet it down.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Set down the body, ſouldiers.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou hallowed relique, thou rich diamond
cut with thine own duſt; thou for whoſe wide fame
the world appears too narrow, mans all thoughts,
had they all tongues, too ſilent; thus I bow
to thy moſt honour'd aſhes; though an enemy,
yet friend to all thy worths: ſleep peaceably;
happineſſe crown thy ſoul, and in thy earth
ſome Lawrel fix his ſeat, there grow, and flouriſh,
and make thy grave an everlaſting triumph.
Fare well all glorious Wars, now thou art gone,
and honeſt Arms adieu: all noble Battels
maintain'd in thirſt of honour, not of blood,
fare well for ever.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Was this Romane, Uncle,
ſo good a man?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou never knew'ſt thy father.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: He di'd before I was born.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: This worthy Romane
was ſuch another piece of endleſſe honour,
ſuch a brave ſoul dwelt in him: their proportions
and faces were not much unlike, boy: excellent natures,
ſee how it works into his eyes, mine own boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: The multitudes of theſe men, and their fortunes,
could never make me fear yet: one mans goodneſſe—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O now thou pleaſeſt me: weep ſtill, my childe,
as if thou ſaw'ſt me dead; with ſuch a flux
or flood of ſorrow: ſtill thou pleaſeſt me.
And worthy ſouldiers, pray receive theſe pledges,
theſe hatchments of our griefs, and grace us ſo much
to place 'em on his Hearſe. Now if ye pleaſe,
bear off the noble burden; raiſe his pile
high as Olympus, making heaven to wonder
to ſee a ſtar upon earth outſhining theirs.
And ever loved, ever living be
thy honoured and moſt ſacred memory.

sp.speaker: Dru.
sp.l: Thou haſt done honeſtly, good Caratach,
●nd when thou di●ſt, a thouſand vertuous Romanes
ſhall ſing thy ſoul to heaven. Now march on, ſouldiers.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Now dry thine eyes, my boy.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Are they all gone?
I could have wept this hour yet.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Come, take cheer,
and raiſe thy ſpirit, childe: if but this day
thou canſt bear out thy faintneſſe, the night coming
I'll faſhion our eſcape.

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: Pray fear not me;
indeed I am very heartie.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Be ſo ſtill;
his miſchiefs leſſen, that controls his ill.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: What do I ail, i' th' name of heaven? I did but ſee her,
and ſee her die: ſhe ſtinks by this time ſtrongly,
abominably ſtinks: ſhe was a woman,
a thing I never car'd for: but to die ſo,
ſo confidently, bravely, ſtrongly; O the devil,
I have the bots, by—; ſhe ſcorn'd us, ſtrangely,
all we could do, or durſt do; threatned us
with ſuch a noble anger, and ſo governed
with ſuch a fiery ſpirit—; the plain bots;
a—upon the bots, the love-bots: hang me,
hang me even out o' th' way, directly hang me.
O pennie pipers, and moſt painful penners
of bountiful new ballads, what a ſubject,
what a ſweet ſubject for your ſilver ſounds,
is crept upon ye?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Here he is; have at him. Sings.

l.hi: She ſet the ſword unto her brest,
great pitie it was to ſee,
That three drops of her life-warm blood,

sp.l: Art thou there, bonny boy? and ifaith how doſt thou?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Well, gramercie, how doſt thou? h' as found me,
ſented me out: the ſhame the devil ow'd me,
h' as kept his day with. And what news, Junius?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: It was an old tale ten thouſand times told,
of a young Lady was turn'd into mold,
her life was lovely, her death it was bold.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: A cruel rogue; now h' as drawn purſue on me,
he hunts me like a devil. No more ſinging;
thou haſt got a cold: come, let's go drink ſome Sack, boy.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Why doſt thou laugh?
what Mares neſt haſt thou found?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.
I cannot laugh alone: Decius, Demetrius,
Curius: O my ſides. Ha, ha, ha, ha,
the ſtrangeſt jeſt.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Prethee no more.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: The admirableſt fooling.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Thou art the prettieſt fellow.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Sirs.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Why Junius,
prethee away, ſweet Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Let me ſing then.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.p: Whoa, here's a ſtir now: ſing a ſong o' ſix pence, by—(if) prethee; — on 't: Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I muſt either ſing, or laugh.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And what 's your reaſon?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: What 's that to you?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And I muſt whiſtle.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Do ſo.
O, I hear 'em coming.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I have a little buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt not go, believe it: what a Gentleman of thy ſweet converſation?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Captain Junius,
ſweet Captain, let me go with all celerity;
things are not always one: and do not queſtion,
nor jeer, nor gybe: none of your doleful ditties,
nor your ſweet converſation: you will finde then
I may be anger'd.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: By no means, Petillius;
anger a man that never knew paſſion?
'tis moſt impoſſible: a noble Captain,
a wiſe and generous Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Tom puppie,
leave this way to abuſe me: I have found ye,
but for your mothers ſake I will forgive ye.
Your ſubtil underſtanding may diſcover
(as you think) ſome trim toy to make you merry;
ſome ſtraw to tickle ye; but do not truſt to 't;
y' are a young man, and may do well; be ſober;
carry your ſelf diſcreetly.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Yes forſooth.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: How does the brave Petillius?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Monſtrous merry:
we two were talking what a kinde of thing
I was when I was in love; what a ſtrange monſter
for little boys and girls to wonder at;
how like a fool I lookt.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: So they do all,
like great dull ſlavering fools.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Petillius ſaw too.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: No more of this; 'tis ſcurvie: peace.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: How naſtily,
indeed how beaſtly all I did became me?
how I forgot to blow my noſe? there he ſtands,
an honeſt and a wiſe man; if himſelf
(I dare avouch it boldly, for I know it)
ſhould finde himſelf in love—

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I am angry.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Surely his wiſe ſelf would hang his beaſtly ſelf,
his underſtanding ſelf ſo mawl his aſſe-ſelf—

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: He's bound to do it; for he knows the follies,
the poverties, and baſeneſſe that belongs to 't,
h' as read upon the reformations long.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: He has ſo.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: 'T is true, and he muſt do 't:
nor is it fit indeed any ſuch coward—

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: You'll leave prating.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Should dare come neer the Regiments, ſpecially
thoſe curious puppies (for believe there are ſuch)
that onely love behaviours: thoſe are dog-whelps,
dwindle away, becauſe a woman dies well;
commit with paſſions onely: fornicate
with the free ſpirit meerly: you, Petillius,
for you have long obſerv'd the world.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Doſt thou hear?
I'll beat thee damnably within theſe three hours:
go pray; may be I'll kill thee. Farewel, Jack daws. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: What a ſtrange thing he's grown?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am glad he is ſo:
and ſtranger he ſhall be, before I leave him.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Is 't poſſible her meer death—▪

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I obſerv'd him,
and found him taken, infinitely taken
with her bravery: I have follow'd him,
and ſeen him kiſſe his ſword ſince, court his ſcabbard,
call dying, dainty deer; her brave minde, miſtris;
caſting a thouſand ways, to give thoſe forms,
that he might lie with 'em, and get old Armors:
he had got me o' th' hip once: it ſhall go hard, friends,
but he ſhall find his own coin.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: How now Macer?
is Judas yet come in? Enter Judas.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Yes, and has loſt
moſt of his men too. Here he is.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: What news?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: I have lodg'd him; rouze him he that dares.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Where, Judas?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: On a ſteep rock, i' th' woods, the boy too with him,
and there he ſwears he will keep his Chriſtmas, Gentlemen,
but he will come away with full conditions,
bravely, and like a Britain: he paid part of us,
yet I think we fought bravely: for mine own part,
I was four ſeveral times at half ſword with him,
twice ſtood his partizan: but the plain truth is,
he's a meer devil, and no man: i' th' end he ſwing'd us,
and ſwing'd us ſoundly too: he fights by With-craft:
yet for all that I ſee him lodg'd,

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Take more men,
and ſcout him round. Macer, march you along.
What victuals has he?

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Not a piece of Bisket,
not ſo much as will ſtop a tooth; nor water,
more then they make themſelves: they lie
juſt like a brace of bear-whelps, cloſe, and crafty,
ſucking their fingers for their food.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Cut off then
all hope of that way: take ſufficient forces.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: But uſe no foul play, on your lives: that man
that does him miſchief by deceit, I'll kill him.

sp.speaker: Macer.
sp.l: He ſhall have fair play, he deſerves it.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Heark ye,
what ſhould I do there then? you are brave Captains,
moſt valiant men; go up your ſelves; uſe vertue,
ſee what will come on 't: pray the Gentleman
to come down, and be taken. Ye all know him,
I think ye have felt him too: there ye ſhall finde him,
his ſword by his ſide, plums of a pound weight by him
will make your chops ake: you'll finde it a more labour
to win him living, then climbing of a Crowes neſt.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Away, and compaſſe him; we ſhall come up
I am ſure within theſe two hours. Watch him cloſe.

sp.speaker: Macer.
sp.l: He ſhall flee thorow the air, if he eſcape us.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: What's this loud lamentation?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: The dead body
of the great Penyus is new come to th' Camp Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Macer
sp.l: By himſelf, they ſay.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I fear'd that fortune.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Peace guide him up to heaven.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: Away good Macer. Exeunt Macer and Judas.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: If thou be'ſt guilty,
ſome ſullen plague thou hat'ſt moſt light upon thee:
the Regiment return on Junius,
hee well deſerves it.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Draw out three Companies,
yours Decius, Junius, and thou Petillius,
and make up inſtantly to Caratach,
he's in the wood before ye; we ſhall follow
after due ceremony done to the dead,
the noble dead: Come, let's go burn the body.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: The Regiment given from me; diſgrac'd openly;
in love too with a trifle to abuſe me?
A merry world, a fine world: ſerv'd ſeven yeers
to be an aſſe o' both ſides, ſweet Petillius,
you have brought your hogs to a fine market: you are wiſe, Sir,
your honourable brain-pan full of crotchets,
an underſtanding Gentleman; your projects
caſt with aſſurance ever: wouldſt not thou now
be bang'd about the pate, Petillius?
anſwer to that ſweet ſouldier; ſurely, ſurely,
I think ye would; pull'd by the noſe, kick'd; hang thee,
thou art the arrant'ſt raſcall: truſt thy wiſdome
with any thing of weight; the winde with feathers.
Out ye blind puppie; you command? you govern?
dig for a groat a day, or ſerve a ſwine-herd;
too noble for thy nature too. I muſt up;
but what I ſhall do there, let time diſcover. Exit.

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Macer and Judas, with meat and a bottle.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Hang it o'th' ſide o'th' rock, as though the Britains
ſtole hither to relieve him; who firſt ventures
to fetch it off, is ours. I cannot ſee him.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: He lies cloſe in a hole above, I know it,
gnawing upon his anger: ha? no, 'tis not he,

sp.speaker: Macer
sp.l: 'Tis but the ſhaking of the boughs.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: — ſhake 'em,
I am ſure they ſhake me ſoundly. There.

sp.speaker: Macer
sp.l: 'Tis nothing.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Make no noiſe: if he ſtir, a deadly tempeſt
of huge ſtones fall upon us: 'tis done: away cloſe. Ex^t.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Sleep ſtil, ſleep ſweetly child, 'tis all thou feedſt on.
No gentle Britain neer; no valiant charitie
to bring thee food? poor knave, thou art ſick, extreme ſick,
almoſt grown wild for meat; and yet thy goodneſſe
will not confeſſe, nor ſhow it. All the woods
are double lin'd with ſouldiers; no way left us
to make a noble ſcape: I'll ſit down by thee,
and when thou wak'ſt, either get meat to ſave thee,
or loſe my life i'th' purchaſe. Good gods comfort thee.

sp.speaker: Guide
sp.l: Ye are not far off now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Draw the Companies
the cloſeſt way thorow the woods; we'll keep on this way.

sp.speaker: Guide
sp.l: I will Sir: half a furlong more you'll come
within the ſight o'th' Rock; keep on the left ſide,
you'll be diſcoverd elſe: I'll lodge your Companies
in the wilde vines beyond ye.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Do ye mark him?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Yes, and am ſorry for him.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: pray let me ſpeak two words with you.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Walk afore,
I'll overtake ye ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: I will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Now, Captain.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: You have oft told me, you have lov'd me, Junius.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Moſt ſure I told you truth then.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: And that love
ſhould not deny me any honeſt thing.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: It ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Dare ye ſwear it?
I have forgot all paſſages between us
that have been ill, forgiven too, forgot you.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.p: What would this man have? By— I do, Sir, ſo it be fit to grant ye.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt honeſt.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Why, then I'll do it.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Kill mee.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Pray kill me.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Kill ye?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I, kill me quickly, ſuddenly,
now kill me.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: On what reaſon? ye amaze me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: If ye do love me, kill me, ask me not why:
I would be kill'd, and by you.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Mercy on me,
What ails this man? Petillius.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Pray ye diſpatch me,
ye are not ſafe whileſt I live: I am dangerous,
troubled extremely, even to miſchief, Junius,
an enemie to all good men: fear not, 'tis juſtice;
I ſhall kill you elſe.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Tell me but the cauſe,
and I will do it.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I am diſgrac'd, my ſervice
ſlighted, and unrewarded by the Generall,
my hopes left wilde and naked; beſides theſe,
I am grown ridiculous, an aſſe, a folly
I dare not truſt my ſelf with: Prethee kill me.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: All theſe may be redeem'd as eaſily
as you would heal your finger.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Nay —

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Stay, I'll do it,
you ſhall not need your anger: But firſt, Petillius,
you ſhall unarm your ſelf; I dare not truſt
a man ſo bent to miſchief.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: There's my ſword;
and do it handſomely.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: yes, I will kill ye,
beleeve that certaine: but firſt i'll lay before ye
the moſt extreme fool ye have plaid in this,
the honour purpoſ'd for ye, the great honour
the Generall intended ye,

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: And then I'll kill ye,
becauſe ye ſhall die miſerable. Know Sir,
the Regiment was given me, but till time
call'd ye to do ſome worthie deed might ſtop
the peoples ill thoughts of ye for Lord Penyus,
I mean his death. How ſoon this time's come to ye,
and haſted by Swetonius? Go, ſayes he,
Junius and Decius, and go thou Petillius;
diſtinctly, thou Petillius, and draw up,
to take ſtout Caratach: there's the deed purpoſ'd,
a deed to take off all faults, of all natures:
And thou Petillius; Mark it, there's the honour,
and that done, all made even.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: No, I'll kill ye.
He knew thee abſolute, and full in ſouldier,
daring beyond all dangers, found thee out
according to the boldneſſe of thy ſpirit,
a ſubject, ſuch a ſubject.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Heark ye Junius,
I will live now.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: By no means. Wooed thy worth,
held thee by the chin up, as thou ſankſt, and ſhew'd thee
how honour held her arms out: Come, make ready,
ſince ye will die an aſſe.

sp.speaker: Petil.
sp.l: Thou wilt not kill me.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: By— but I will Sir: I'll have no man dan|gerous
live to deſtroy me afterward. Beſides, you have gotten
honour enough, let young men riſe now. Nay,
I do perceive too by the Generall, (which is
one main cauſe ye ſhall die) how ere he carry it,
ſuch a ſtrong doting on ye, that I fear,
you ſhall command in chief: how are we paid then?
Come, if you will pray, diſpatch it.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Is there no way?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Not any way to live.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: I will do any thing,
redeem my ſelf at any price: good Junius,
let me but die upon the Rock, but offer
my life up like a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: You will ſeek then
to out-doe every man.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Beleeve it Junius,
you ſhall goe ſtroak by ſtroak with me.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: You'll leave off too,
as you are noble, and a ſouldier,
for ever theſe mad fancies.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Dare ye truſt me?
By all that's good and honeſt.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: There's your ſword then,
and now come on a new man: Vertue guide thee. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Caratach and Hengo on the Rock.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Courage my Boy, I have found meat: look Hengo,
look where ſome bleſſed Britain, to preſerve thee,
has hung a li●tle food and drink: cheer up Boy,
do not forſake me now.

sp.speaker: Hengo.
sp.l: O Uncle, Uncle,
I feel I cannot ſtay long: yet I'll fetch it,
to keep your noble life: Uncle, I am heart whole,
and would live.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt, long I hope.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: But my head, Uncle:
me thinks the Rock goes round. Enter Macer & Jud.

sp.speaker: Macer.
sp.l: Mark 'em well, Judas.

sp.speaker: Jud.
sp.l: Peace, as you love your life.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Do not you hear
the noiſe of bels?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: of bels Boy? 'tis thy fancie,
alas, thy bodie's full of wind.

sp.speaker: Hengo.
sp.l: me thinks Sir,
they ring a ſtrange ſad knell, a preparation
to ſome neer funerall of State: nay, weep not,
mine owne ſweet Uncle, you will kill me ſooner.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O my poor chicken.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Fie, faint-hearted Uncle:
Come, tie me in your belt, and let me down.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I'll go my ſelf, Boy.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: No, as ye love mee, Uncle;
I will not eat it, if I doe not fetch it;
the danger onely I deſire: pray tie me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I will, and all my care hang ore thee: come child,
my valiant-child.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: Let me down apace, Uncle,
and ye ſhall ſee how like a Daw I'll whip it
from all their policies: for 'tis moſt certain
a Roman train: and ye muſt hold me ſure too,
you'll ſpoil all elſe. When I have brought it Uncle,
wee'll be as merry —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Go i'th' name of heaven Boy.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: Quick, quick, Uncle, I have it. Oh.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What aileſt thou?

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: O my beſt Uncle, I am ſlain.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I ſee yee, and heaven direct my hand: deſtruction
sp.stage: Caratach kils Judas with a ſtone from the Rock.
sp.l: go with thy coward ſoul. How doſt thou Boy?
Oh villain, pocky villain.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: O Uncle, Uncle,
oh how it pricks mee: am I preſerv'd for this?
extremely pricks me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Coward, raſcall Coward,
dogs eat thy fleſh.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Oh I bleed hard: I faint too, out upon 't,
how ſick I am? the lean Rogue, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Look Boy,
I have laid him ſure enough.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: Have ye knockt his brains out?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I warrant thee for ſtirring more: cheer up, child.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Hold my ſides hard, ſtop, ſtop, oh wretched fortune,
muſt we part thus? Still I grow ſicker, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Heaven look upon this noble child.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: I once hop'd
I ſhould have liv'd to have met theſe bloody Romans
at my ſwords point, to have reveng'd my father,
to have beaten 'em: oh hold me hard. But Uncle—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt live ſtill I hope Boy. Shall I draw it?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Ye draw away my ſoul then. I would live
a little longer; ſpare me heavens, but onely
to thank you for your tender love. Good Uncle,
good noble Uncle weep not.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Oh my chicken,
my deer Boy, what ſhall I loſe?

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: Why, a child,
that muſt have died how-ever: had this ſcap'd me,
feaver or famine: I was born to die, Sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But thus unblown, my Boy?

sp.speaker: Heng.
sp.l: I goe the ſtraighter
my journey to the gods: Sure I ſhall know ye
when ye come, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Yes, Boy.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: And I hope
wee ſhall enjoy together that great bleſſedneſſe
you told me of.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Moſt certain, child.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: I grow cold,
mine eyes are going.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Lift 'em up.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: Pray for me;
and noble Uncle, when my bones are aſhes,
think of your little Nephew. Mercie.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Mercie.
You bleſſed angels take him.

sp.speaker: Hengo
sp.l: Kiſſe me: ſo.
Farewell, farewell. Dies.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Farewell the hopes of Britain,
thou Royall graft, Farewell for ever. Time and Death,
ye have done your worſt. Fortune now ſee, now proudly
pluck off thy vail, and view thy triumph: Look,
look what thou haſt brought this Land to. Oh fair flower,
how lovely yet thy ruines ſhow, how ſweetly
even death embraces thee! The peace of heaven,
the fellowſhip of all great ſouls be with thee.
sp.stage: Enter Petillius & Junius on the rock.
sp.l: Hah? dare ye Romans? ye ſhall win me bravely.
Thou art mine. Fight.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Not yet, Sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Breathe ye, ye poor Romans,
and come up all, with all your ancient valours,
like a rough winde I'll ſhake your ſouls, and ſend 'em—

div.stage: Enter Swetonius, and all the Roman Captains.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Yeeld thee bold Caratach; by all —
as I am ſouldier, as I envie thee,
I'll uſe thee like thy ſelf, the valiant Britain.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Brave ſoldier yeeld; thou ſtock of Arms and Honor,
thou filler of the world with fame and glory.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Moſt worthy man, we'l woo thee, be thy priſoners.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Excellent Britain, do me but that honour,
that more to me then Conqueſts, that true happineſſe,
to be my friend.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O Romans, ſee what here is:
had this Boy liv'd —

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: For Fames ſake, for thy Swords ſake,
as thou deſireſt to build thy vertues greater:
by all that's excellent in man, and honeſt —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I do beleeve: Ye have had me a brave foe;
make me a noble friend, and from your goodneſſe,
give this Boy honourable earth to lie in.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: He ſhall have fitting Funerall.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I yeeld then,
not to your blowes, but your brave courteſies.

sp.speaker: Petill.
sp.l: Thus we conduct then to the arms of Peace
the wonder of the world.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Thus I embrace thee, Flouriſh.
and let it be no flattery that I tell thee,
thou art the onely Souldier.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: How to thank ye
I muſt hereafter finde upon your uſage.
I am for Rome?

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Ye muſt.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Then Rome ſhall know
the man that makes her ſpring of glory grow.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Petillius, you have ſhown much worth this day,
redeem'd much errour,
ye have my love again, preſerve it. Junius,
with you I make him equall in the Regiment.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: The elder and the nobler: I'll give place, Sir.

sp.speaker: Swet.
sp.l: Ye ſhew a friends ſoul.
March on, and through the Camp in every tongue.
the Vertues of great Caratach be ſung. Exeunt.
